RATING: 8.3
My first game, and still one of my favourites. 
There's no ceiling -- the same cards can be used to imagine and tell infinite stories.
The ultimate "don't play to win, play to have fun" game. 

I play boardgames to interact with people. Dixit offers a warm and special way of doing that.

(Unless you're playing with the people that deliberately use only references which not everyone knows.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This really gives the creative side of your brain a heavy workout! The cards are beautifully detailed, intricate, and open to many interpretations. It's incredible when you've had a card in your hand for several turns without any idea of how you could play it, only to see it become a perfect fit for another player's turn. Likewise when you see another player interpret cards in a different way to you. It requires a certain amount of energy or spark, but I'm yet to play this with a group that hasn't enjoyed it. Sometimes it can take a while for the active player to take their turn, and if this occurs frequently we tend to allow other players to step in and take their turn instead, which keeps the game flowing and doesn't affect the game balance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Card game version of Barbarossa (Klaus Teuber, 1988) where you have a handful of very unusually drawn (art) cards and you take turns being either the storyteller or one of the other players.  The storyteller tries to be neither too vague nor too specific in describing their card, and the other players select a card from their hand that they feel best matches the description given by the storyteller.  Points are awarded to the storyteller if at least one (but not all!) people guess his card, and by the other players if they guess the storyteller's card AND if other people guess their cards instead.  It's most difficult and least lucrative being the storyteller but this role moves around the table each turn.

The game is infinitely expandable and plays very well as a light humorous filler for large groups.  I can see this going over very well with non-gamers.  Needs at least 3 players and can play up to well as many as you like really but I think officially 7.

Own the [boardgame=55660]Quest[/boardgame], [boardgame=138547]Odyssey[/boardgame], [boardgame=121288]Journey[/boardgame], and [boardgame=145325]Origins[/boardgame] expansions.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[COLOR=#FFFFFF][BGCOLOR=#FF9933][b]aaj's FAVORITE PARTY GAME[/b][/BGCOLOR][/COLOR]
Dixit is right up there with Sushi Go and Century as one of my favorite ways to introduce people to the hobby. Not only that, it's a boatload of fun with people who already know how to play. This subtle clue-based game is always interesting, and always morphs depending on the people you are playing with. 

The game mechanics are very simple to A2A: one player chooses a hint, all players play a card that they think matches that hint, and then players vote on which card the active player laid down. Extremely simple, loads of fun.

Dixit thrives on the surreal artwork and the beautiful tension of clue-giving. Every time you give a clue, you need to evaluate the people playing with you: the kinds of things they know and appreciate, and the kinds of things they won't know at all. Your job is to give a hint that's good enough that some people will get it, but not so obvious that everyone gets it. But your clue can be anything: a word, a phrase, a sound effect, or even a YouTube video!

Dixit is simply the best game in so many categories. With Odyssey, it's my favorite large-group game, and any version is my favorite party game. The subtle clues required to do well and the group interaction this provokes make Dixit a perfect 10 game for me. Oh, [thing=181304][/thing] is fun, and I enjoy both games, but Dixit balances its remarkable depth with an incredible accessibility that Mysterium just doesn't have. Dixit would definitely make my boardgaming hall of fame.

[COLOR=#FFFFFF][BGCOLOR=#66CC33][b] EXPANSION(s) OWNED: [/b][/BGCOLOR][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

[thing=92828][/thing] [BGCOLOR=#00cc00][b] 10[/b] [/BGCOLOR] - Odyssey is a fantastic addition to Dixit (it should be the base game by default). The 12-player option is incredible and gives a lot of extra flexibility with different game groups. Plus, the artwork is still amazing, like every expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of those games you can easily teach to any one and MOST people like it although we have at least one family member who doesn't like it. It's harder than it looks. I always find it fun. As a clue giver, choose a card from a choice of surreal picture cards in your hand and give a clue - not too obvious so everyone guesses, and not so obscure that no one gets it. The other players contribute a card they think will match your clue. Mix up the cards and the other players guess which card was your card. Sometimes even an obvious clue will win out because the other players have cards that match the clue so perfectly. Fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I love the artwork and scope for creative thinking. Expansions help to add variety - I have Dixit 2, which is equally great, and blends in nicely.

So far, it's been fantastic with 4-6 players (with non-gamers too), and fun using the two player co-op variant from the BGG threads. I didn't enjoy the three player variant so much (from the rulebook) - choosing two cards to match the storyteller's clue was just too difficult and ended up with too many arbitrary cards in every selection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dixit is absolutely gorgeous to look at. And here it is not just for eye candy since the whole game lives around the art. I think this is the biggest achievement of the game. and it shows that the designers have been very ambitious. You could have made the very same game with less inspiring art but the result would have landed far from where it is now.  

Mechanically the game does not offer anything extraordinary. Technically the game is very much like Rappakalja. All the magic comes from your own head, and at least for me Dixit succeeds in doing this. But you have to be careful with who you play. I reckon that Dixit will become a very dull experience with someone blessed with the imagination of a depressed cabbage (or it just might be the most hilarious thing ever).

However, the base game has too few cards because you see all of them in every single game. This becomes a bit repetitive after a while and thus you need to invest in an expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Anyway, I'd like to own this game, and since my husband doesn't hate it, it has a better chance of being acquired.

RATING: 6
This is a neat party game but it's not as fun(ny) as I was hoping it'd be. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game and really "neat", but when I bust out a party game I'm usually with a bunch of non-gamers (or drunk gamers) who are just looking to have fun and measure that amount of fun by how much laughing is happening. There are plenty of other games out there that register higher on that scale. That said, I do like the game, just not for the situation I bought it for...

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The art in this game has a very mystical/tarot sort of feel to it which I imagine to be deliberate as the premise is simply for people to take turns creating a story based on one of six cards in their hand and then mixing it with other players cards (that they each selected based on the story the main player told that round) so that all players but the story teller can bet on which card is the story tellers. Points are scored laughs are had and in general I would prefer this to Apples to Apples as far as party games go. My issue with the game is it is limited by the imagination of the players playing, and often breaks down into humorous but shallow play or fractures between literal and metaphysical leanings of the people playing. Dixie is fine for a few hands at a party which is where I'd bring it as a nice ice breaker for casuals but that's about it IMO.

RATING: 5
+ Sure, the artwork is neat-looking.
- The entertainment in this game hinges on people being a little "out there" and ridiculous; With our normal group, this was just a little bland.


Why it's previously-owned:
This game is so dependent on playing with other very creative types.  Most of the people in my group who enjoyed playing party-style games ended up not being so creative when push came to shove.
I traded this away for YINSH.  Our favorite party game still remains Time's Up; we'll always pull that out when we have a crowd.

RATING: 6.5
Beautiful art and nice components for a cute party game. Dixit shows how a game can be extremely simple and still fun. It doesn't offer a lot of laughter, which may be a limit for a party game, but it can bring some good puzzles and a nice social experience.

Unfortunately Dixit has dropped a little for me over time. I used to play it a lot and I really liked it, but game after game I realized that my enjoyment depends terribly on the people around the table. It happened often to see round after round of obvious choices, when players were not creative enough and just said something to get over with their turn. My rating therefore goes from 8 to 6.5. I like it, but I want to play it with the right group.

Rating without the expansions: 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One player is the storyteller for the turn and looks at the images on the 6 cards in her hand. From one of these, she makes up a sentence and says it out loud (without showing the card to the other players).

Each other player selects the card in their hands which best matches the sentence and gives the selected card to the storyteller, without showing it to the others.

The storyteller shuffles her card with all the received cards. All pictures are shown face up and every player has to bet upon which picture was the storyteller's.

RATING: 6
Seemed fine. One person I talked with about it commented that, if you're playing it well and making the answer evenly balanced with the other cards, then basically you're making everything a random guess. So winning is basically random.

That's probably true. But if you're playing games to win, you should probably stick to 2-player games and, more importantly, this isn't the sort of game where you play to win. It's more like Cards Against Humanity where the goal is to have a nice social experience. I don't think it does that in a particularly amazing way, but it's reasonable and friendly to all ages/genders, so that's a pretty good selling point.

RATING: 9
4-12(6)

Okay, a really, really solid party game that's not quite as arbitrary as something like Apples to Apples. Will play differently with every group and will often be a riot, especially if the presenters and all get into it. Great, great game.

The only pratfall is that it can tend to fall into inside jokes / references too easily. In several groups there have been references to TV shows / books / etc. that only a few of the players have watched.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I found Dixit's surreal art delightful and the game's concept original. The player whose turn it is reveals something about one of their cards.  The other players must then choose cards that best reflect that description.  All then vote on what they think the best matches are. In order to maximise their points the storyteller needs their card to be voted for, but not by too many players. Hence, descriptions tend to the oblique.

Although the artwork is lovely and the concept is original, I just don't find the game play terrifically engaging. For that party game slot this would fill, I prefer something dumber and uproarious-er.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Got as a christmas present from Linus. My 100:th game. See dixit Odyssey...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I am almost ashamed at how long it took me to get around to playing this game. As a person who tends to get too competitive with party games, Dixit is somehow very disarming for me. RATING: 6
Wonderful game. Works especially well with my wife and family who aren't typical game lovers. However, I tend to be very choosey about who I play it with experienced gamer-wise. It can be a real grind to play with a brace of players piggy-backing each other with references to things you haven't heard of. Be especially careful if it's a group of well-established friends whom you don't know well. You're likely to feel very left out of the loop.

By the way, the artwork is bloody glorious.

RATING: 7
A nice thoughtful game with very pretty and inspiring artwork. Have played on three occasions, in 3,3 and 6 players. I cannot recommend the game in 3, unless you play w modified rules (it's ok+ then). It's great fun in 6, and perfectly suitable for people who are not gamers. A concern of mine is that after a total of only 6 games, I feel that I've really seen all the cards. While there's an almost unlimited amount of ways to describe a card, most attempts tend to tap central ideas/concepts of a particular design. I start recognizing patterns in the way people reason around a particular card. For me, this somewhat detracts from the fun. That is to say, you may want to consider expansions early on, to promote longevity.

RATING: 8
If it is your turn, describe one of your cards with a cryptic sentence. Otherwise pick a card matching whatever wierdness the player who's turn it is say. Then vote! If everyone or no one picks the right card, you score none. If some of the other pick the right card you score. And for the other players score for each player voting for your card. Simple and fun.

RATING: 5
Decent party game with simple rules and interesting, abstract art. 

Creativity is tested, but often goes unrewarded when the other players don't understand where you are coming from. It also runs into the Apples to Apples problem of just not having a good card to associate with the story.

Replayability is also an issue. For a game that is supposed to amaze you with its art, seeing the same artwork over and over even if there's a different "story" associated with it makes the art much less amazing.

RATING: 7.5
In general, party games fall flat because many resort to a popularity contest to determine who gets the points.  Dixit changes this and is likely the first party game to make my list of good game designs.  The artwork is exceptional and works for so many elements.  Teaching the game is very easy, even to non-gamers.  A definite plus is that both gamers and non can play and both find enjoyment.  If you are shy of party games, this one might shift your mind.

RATING: 8
Dixit is a fantastic game when playing with a large group of players.  With too few the scoring mechanism feels a little broken.  The fact that it is a party game means that scoring is less important, but still.  I prefer this with a full compliment of players.

The game is actually a bit similar to "apples to apples". Players receive a hand of cards (wonderfully illustrated) and try to form phrases based on the illustrations.  You can't be too obvious or too obscure.  It's engaging, challenging and very fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Abstract fun.  The group you play with makes a big difference in this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
If I rated after 2 plays it would be much higher. But after several plays some flaws started showing- it can feel repetitive when you get the same old cards and your brain keeps thinking of clues you've already given/heard for that card. Also, there's a weird dynamic between playing the game for fun and playing to win. The game is most fun when you give strange and interesting clues. But if you want to win the best type of clue to give is one that is a specific inside reference that only one other player will recognize. 

Still, this is a fun game, and it's one that has always been a big hit with many different audiences of non-gamers. Definitely a worthwhile game to get.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Apples to Apples with pictures? Well, yes, but I think Dixit allows for greater creativity and a richer experience. Great family/party game, though it can be a little "thinky" with certain players, so it may not be the best choice if you're looking for a raucous party game. There will be laughter and subdued excitement, however, and so it's very versatile; great for couples parties or even for an afternoon with family. With a single set, you'll see the same cards a lot, but they all have different aspects you can focus on, and sometimes considering previous experiences with cards can become part of the strategy. First impressions will sometimes cause people to balk when having to give the clue, but encourage them to hang in there as most people will quickly get the hang of it after a single game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The downside I can see is repeated plays with the same group will become stale quickly. How many different words/phrases/ideas are invoked when you see the same image multiple times?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
UPDATE: 8/26/13: I didn't think it was possible to play this game without having a ton of fun, but play with the wrong people and it can happen.  I still love this game, but it is obviously not universally fun.  Why do I hate Apples to Apples? Because the outcome is always nothing more than a last second judgement call and usually as an attempt to make a lame joke.  Dixit doesn't have that flaw. The scoring is well defined and not subject to judgement. Also, the best strategy I have found has nothing to do with how well you know the people you are playing with. One of these "wrong" people tried to play Dixit like Apples to Apples and failed miserably. He tried to zero in on me by picking hints he thought only I would understand.  Of course, Dixit can break a bit if people chose not to put down a card that resembles the hint, but you get more points by guessing it right and fooling others into picking your card.

NEW!
I took this game to a board game night party with some friends.  This was only the second time I played the game and it is every bit as wonderful as the first playthrough.  My first expansion also came today and the cards are just as amazing and weird as those that come with the base game.  Excellent game.  Easy to understand.  Easy to explain.  And the most important part is that anyone who has played it with me so far has loved it.

OLD
I have never played a more fun party game than Dixit.  With the right group of people, this game is a laugh out loud good time.  The rules and process are simple and easy to explain to new players.  It takes some thought to manage any strategy, but it is hands down far better than that piece of crap Apples to Apples that ruined party games for me.  The cards are all so strange and interesting that I would get excited every time I had to draw a new one and I would have a hard time waiting for my turn to be the active player because I have such a good or funny idea for a hint. The art work is top notch.  I want all of the expansions for this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

boring boring boring.... I don't understand why that game is so popular

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Bought as a gift for my daughter (so not listed as owned by me) but mentioned here because the inside of the lid was personally illustrated (beautifully) and signed with a message by the artist Marie Cardouat. 

Plays very like the dictionary game where one person selects a card and creates some vague prose to summarise the card, the others pick a card from their hand that is best summed up by the words. Very simple but incredibly engaging.

Very much an after dinner game. Huge replayability value.

Fun party game that makes Apples to Apples completely obsolete. The artwork is fantastic, eye-catching, thought provoking and inspires creativity in a way Apples to Apples just didn't. It allows for some strategy, as you want to deliver a message about your image that some will be able to decipher, but that is not be so obvious that everyone figures it out. Finding a phrase, sound, or song lyric that finds this middle ground between vague and blunt is  the core of what makes the game enjoyable. Plus, hey, bunny shaped player pieces.

RATING: 8
Lok: BHFE02
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
"Simple" is the first word I think of when I approach this game.  It is just so basic in the mechanism that it gives me that "why didn't someone think of this before" feel.  Of course, this HAS been thought of before in some fashion (particularly Thingamajig.)  But what makes this game so accessible to new players is the awesome artwork.  There is so much you can do as a story-teller with these pictures.  I should note, though, that it seems playing regularly with the same group might cause the game to quickly grow stale.  Since you see every card in the game, you really lose some of that replayability that I would prefer in a party game like this.

Initially I thought I wasn't going to like this game at all.  It seemed too easy to score points, dragged on a little long for what it is, and resulted in unsurprising close scores.  However that was a 4-player game.  Now that I've played with 6 I can say that this is almost the default number of players.  With the added players you have more options and the scoring becomes less of a sure thing.  I'm still not sure if this is a premiere party game, but it is enjoyable for occasional play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great family game. We usually end up laughing by the end of each game. I think the game encourages creativity and imagination.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
boring, needs right crowd
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Although I'm not big into the "social" games, this has been a big hit with my group and family. The game is group dependent, but with the right mixture of players the game really shines. It is also great for non-gamers.

Dixit is a party game where players get cards with beautiful(?) art and then one player selects a phrase or sings a song or whatever to describe the card they are playing. The rest of the players then place a card down that they think will match up. Players then see the cards, vote on which one they think was the original storyteller's card and points are scored. However, if everyone or no one selects the storyteller card, the storyteller gets 0 points. So you want to be not so obscure in your hints that everyone guesses your card, but not so vague that no one guesses your card. Plays fairly fast, and the scoring is pretty simple.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The gameplay is so unique compared to most every other game on the market.  It taps into the creative and expressive side of your brain as opposed to the analytical, strategic side.  That is not to say the game is devoid of strategy.  But between the magnificent artwork (my wife to like to hang some of the cards on our walls) and the abstract thought required to play well, typical gamer strategy doesn't enter in to the equation much at all.

This game is fantastic for groups of casual or non-gamers as well, which is always a consideration I have when buying games.

RATING: 7
Beautiful art, but the problem is the game just doesn't come together for me. The balance between giving a good clue yet not too good, is simply too hard to do. Meaning you usually end up giving it away or being way too vague as the storyteller. 

Equally, as the guesser, you have no bloody clue if they have been too vague and it is too easy if they have been too obvious.

It's great that you can explain it in a minute though and be played with non-gamers without a problem, that is it's real strength.

RATING: 9
Great family game. Plays quickly.
Accessible to a wide range of people, from 10 year olds to 99 year olds.

Similar to Apples to Apples, but visual, rather than using cards with definitions.

An expansion would be very helpful since with just 80+ cards you get familiar with the deck.  With more cards there would be greater variation.

Onw caveat - players need to agree not to use "stories" based on a movie/TV show/event that not all players are familiar with, else they are at a disadvantage.

RATING: 3
Combines elements of Apples to Apples, Barbarossa, Cluzzle and Attribut.  It is mostly a parlor game that you play for socializing.  Success in the game depends upon whether you are lucky enough to have a card in your hand that resembles the clue given by the "current" player (which is often weird or an inside joke since he doesn't want everyone to guess the card that he is playing).  Slightly better than Apples-to-Apples since it is a little less subjective (everyone votes, not just one player)... and you are not totally out of the round if you don't have a good card... you can still get points by correctly guessing the card that the "current" player contributed to the secret pile of cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
Love this for the art almost as much for the game.

RATING: 6
20 plays: Prompts creativity in a beautiful way. Official game rules and tokens are poorly designed, and instead of paying by the rules, my daughters and I just make up stories using the cards. But that way of playing is still cool.

What doesn't work well is that the cards are so specific. You can't really just say "Revenge is sweet, said the woman as she walked away from the cliff!"... because that denies that the cliff is made up of negative space or her hair or whatever. I wish the illustrations were more universal and less metaphysically clever --it's hard to craft a story that isn't just literally tied to what you see.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Se reparten seis cartas a cada jugador. En cada turno hay un cuentacuentos que dice una frase que él asocia a una de las cartas. Todos los jugadores escogen una de sus cartas que "peguen" con la frase. Después se descubren todas y cada jugador (excepto el cuenta cuentos) vota, tratando de averiguar qué carta escogió el cuenta cuentos. Si todos aciertan o nadie acierta, todos puntuan dos puntos, menos el cuenta cuentos. Si no, el cuentacuentos y los que acertaron la carta suman tres puntos. Todas las cartas votadas suman además otro punto (excepto la del cuentacuentos). Sencillez extrema. 
Es un juego familiar. El mérito del juego lo dan las ilustraciones, que son preciosas y jugarlo en el grupo adecuado. Para mi gusto es demasiado sencillo y tengo muchas dudas sobre su rejugabilidad. Es como jugar al pictionary con los dibujos ya hechos. No obstante, es un juego que ha tenido mucho exito, y una vez que juegas, es fácil entender por qué. Idóneo para reuniones de no jugones si se quiere una alternativa a los de siempre (tabú, trivial, pictionary, etc).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Gotten so much mileage out of my base set, just finally got my first expansion hoping for a million more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun partyish game, although I could see that some people could naturally struggle with this one given the subtlety required to do well.

One interesting thing that Jonathan did was to use inside information ("Claire" - TV Lost) to describe a card, and ensure that I got it, but Tim/Dave did not. That's a fantastic strategy, but I'm torn whether that would make for a poor game if it happened every single round, as most players would be just guessing randomly, rather than making clever deductions. This could become particularly problematic if husband/wife were playing. "Hawaii vacation, 1993, near the volcano! Ha ha ha!"

Other concern is that there aren't really that many cards, and replayability could be a bit of a problem. Next time I play in a game with Jonathan & some new people, I could use those phrases that I remember from previous games to give us endless points. So I'm very doubtful that the game has much replayability at all.

Jan 2011:  Rating raised from 8 to 9.   Enjoy this game every time we play.  Dixit 2 improves the options even more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game of oblique references. A great party game. Reminiscent of Apples-to-Apples but with an unique twist on the concept. One player chooses a card with an abstract image on it and without revealing it explains that card with a few well chosen words. Other players choose cards from their hands that could also match those words. All cards are mixed and the players try to pick the original image from the added ones. I like that way the rules punish you if you words are too obscure and no-one guesses correctly. Forces you to strike a lovely balance between being too obvious and too cryptic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Amazing artwork! And fun creative game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A definite improvement on the Apples to Apples genre of party game.

Each round, the lead player secretly selects a card from his hand and gives a clue about it.  Hopefully one that is not too hard, but not too easy either.  Then, every other player secretly plays a card that matches the clue given as best as possible.

Cards are then shuffled and flipped face-up, and players guess which of the cards was the actual card played by the clue giver.  Players are awarded points for guessing correctly, and for playing a card that someone else chose.

Overall, a simple party/social game that allows for some creativity in the clue giving portion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Very good family game where the beautiful artwork is front and center. The rules are very simple: each player takes a turn choosing a word/phrase/song and everyone must pick a card from their hand that best matches it. The game is easily picked up by everyone so I love that it can be played by anyone and it's also quick enough to keep the interest of children throughout. The biggest strength of the game is obviously the gorgeous illustrations that could take up so many different meanings. Definitely not a thinky game, but a quick game to play with family and friends.

RATING: 5
I don't think I'm good enough at abstract thinking for this game... I suck at picking topics. :(

Yes, it definitely feels like visual Apples to Apples.

Our first game was fun. I wonder how much longevity this game has in it... very difficult to tell, I think.

I find it kind of weird that you go through the entire deck every game. I didn't like that I got to see basically every single card our first game... makes me less eager to replay, unlike other card games where I want to keep playing to see all the cards.

The artwork is lovely. I think I want Dixit 2 just to see more pretty pictures!

Definitely need the right group for this (i.e., not people who will pick an entirely random topic so everyone throws out nonsense cards while the storyteller is just betting that, in all likeliness, at least one person will bet on their card.) The cleverer the group, the better, I would think.

Update: Dropping to a 5. I'm not very visual, and I don't like A2A enough to ever really want to play... visual A2A.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit takes the basic mechanics of Balderdash and applies it to surrealistic images created by Marie Cardouat, whose child-like style occasionally belies the ominous content of some of the illustrations.  Players take turns acting as the "storyteller" and attempt to give the others a clue describing one of their cards such that at least one player, but not all, can guess which card belongs to the storyteller, among the cards contributed by all the players.  This game encourages you to think creatively in order to come up with a clue that is not too specific or too abstract.  I have to admit that I was skeptical of this game from the very beginning, despite liking the art and components, but it is a lot of fun!  It is a very "right-brain"-type of game and I feel like it fills a gap in my collection.  Sometimes you can judge a game by it's cover after all!  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

[u]December 2010:[/u] Changed my rating system, the game is now rated 8
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I played Dixit Odyssey (with the scoring map and up to 12 players), but in all of my plays cards from Dixit 1, 2 and 3 have been mixed into the game, so I’ve just given the same rating for all of them. I think that the expansions are, unfortunately, essential as the few cards you get in one of the standalone games will quickly get into a rotation. Dixit shines when you don’t see the same cards often so you don’t have the same associations connected to specific cards (sure, you might still do, but with e.g. 300 instead of 100 cards, chances are that you won’t face too many of the same cards, and, furthermore, the other players will have a broader variety of cards of their own to pick from).

Dixit is a great game for kids and families as you really need to be creative and think outside the box! However, I’m not in the target group. I would definitely still play it with family, kids and non-gamers (which is exactly what I’ve done so far), but as a game there isn’t much to it. It’s more like an activity for creative minds, and it’s very good at that; it’s just not a game for me. If playing a “game” that isn’t really a game, I would much rather play Telestrations; it’s not a similar game at all, but Telestrations always make me laugh, it caters the same amount of players and it’s also a partygame/activity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.3
Main Positives: A great party game!

Fun Factor: High
Complexity: With the exception of the scoring, it's not really that difficult to learn it.
Replayability: Yup! Especially with new cards or with new players who could give new ideas to the table.

Main Frustrations and Caveats:
You have to be both smart about your clues at the same time know who can understand them though this didn't take away the enjoyment of playing the game.

RATING: 8
A pretty fantastic party game that kind of makes you get in the heads of the people you play with. There's not a whole lot of "meat" to it, and it's not the kind of party game where you find yourself laughing much if at all. But it's very charming and presents you with some interesting gameplay that's rather unique.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good, interesting family game. It can really stretch your imagination. However, the re-playability is limited as you will invariably see the same cards cropping up for the same themes time and again. There are plenty of expansions now available to add extra cards now which should remove this problem.
EDIT - Adding just one additional pack of cards really increases the variety and improves the game. I would definitely recommend picking up at least one if you are going to play Dixit as a regular family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My second favorite party game (behind The Resistance).  This game combines the best aspects of both Apples to Apples and Balderdash.  All of the cards are pictures.  The active player gives a brief clue about one of his cards, all other players then try to pick a card that also matches that clue.  All non-active players then vote on which picture belongs to the active player.
The trick is that the active player loses if everyone picks his card OR if no one picks his card.  So the active player can't be to obvious but he also can't be too obtuse.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

However, the game itself is clever, fun, creative and brings out the most inventive ideas from people. It serves for a lot of lighthearted banter and good group interaction. It is so unlike anything people have played it is always well received.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
>5 plays
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This light card game involves describing a card, but not too well.  The cards have pretty fantasy art.  Each player is dealt a hand of cards.  The active player selects a card and says up to a few words about it.  Then, everyone else selects one of their cards they think fits that description.  The cards are shuffled together then displayed.  Players then indicate which card they think belonged to the active player.  Points are awarded for guessing correctly and for having your card guessed.  Beware of describing your card too well: if everyone guesses it, you will receive no points.

Received in trade for Incan Gold
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Outstanding all-ages game. Perfect as a party game or a filler game. Fantastic artwork. The artwork truly matters, as it is a primary component of the game. Not just window dressing.

This game is not about how much you know, how strategic you are, or how competitive you are. It is really a test for how creative you can be. If your creative side is strong, you should enjoy the game and do well.

The first player to 30 points is the winner. Players take turns being the active player. Tokens consist of colored wooden bunnies on a scoring track.

The active player secretly selects a card from their hand, and gives a clue that relates to something on the card. All other players then secretly select one card that may also be related to the clue. The cards are shuffled and laid out face up, so it is not possible to know whose cards belong to whom. Then al non-active players vote on which card was played by the active player. The goal of the active player is to get at least one person to guess their card, but not everyone.

If your clue is too obvious, everyone will guess your card, and you get zero points, while everyone else gets points. If your clue is too obscure, nobody will guess your card, you will get zero points and everyone else will score points. If you guess the active player's card, and other people guess your card, you get even more points.

The game plays fairly quickly, and it is a lot of fun trying to come up with excellent clues and enjoying others who do the same when they are the active player.

You may see a runaway leader or a distant player bringing up the rear in scoring, but it usually comes down to 2 or more payers battling to get to 30 points and win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Magical and creative game.  Instant favorite when introducing it to new players.  Seems like it would get old quickly though, if played too often and with the same group of players.  Thus the NEED for expansions.  Time really flies when playing this game.  It's hard to imagine anyone not liking this game (for the first few times at least). It remains to be seen whether this game has longevity though.  I've played it four times with three different game groups in the past three days since getting it.  

Six months and 2 expansions later I'm lowering my rating from a 9 to a 7.  Still a good game, but not quite so magical anymore.  Sigh...

RATING: 5
I have a hard time looking upon Dixit as a serious game. It is a unique form of activity, of course, one to engage in with the entire family... but too much implicit knowledge of people's preferences and habits is needed once people get to know each other well. Analogies which in my opinion are also not games in the way I usuall play them are for example cooking shows which subsequently award points for best presentation. Yes, you can award points for this, but how those are arrived at is difficult to put to words. Now in Dixit the process of point awarding is admittedly not that obfuscated, but still it feels odd to me. What [i]is[/i] a genuine problem is that at times you simply don't have a card which matches the story; and that it is also at times impossible to deduce what the hell someone was talking about given the set of open cards. 

The upshot is that I really cannot make myself care about how well I am doing pointwise (although I usually finish in the top-3, believe it or not), and instead just treat every story as a [i]puzzle[/i] which needs solving rather than a [i]competition[/i] I need to do well at. This helps make Dixit palatable... barely. It's that it only hits the table about two times a year that I will participate; more than this is overasking. The rate given reflects this; otherwise you can easily deduct one or two point from it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A well-designed game that is a bit outside my typical interest level.

RATING: 7
Kids and non-gamers like this one. The card art is evocative and provides ample visual "hooks" to use when coming up with clues to describe the cards. One drawback is the large cards, which are nice for displaying artistic detail to all players around the table, are also somewhat difficult to keep hidden from other players. And because the game is essentially figuring out who played which cards, seeing someone else's hand destroys a good deal of the fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I would describe this game as a mash-up of Apples to Apples and Balderdash.  The current player selects one of his cards, describes it with a "story" and then other players submit their own cards they think match the description.  They are mixed up and players vote.  Points are awarded when your card is chosen.

The slight twist is the storyteller wants to get some, but not all, of the players to vote for his card to put himself in the best position on the scoring track.

Lovely artwork to be sure, and I wouldn't turn down the chance to play again.  But I don't think the gameplay is very original.

RATING: 8
Scratches the same party-game itch as Apples to Apples, but there's something like a balanced game in there. It's a very different skillset from most board games - "provide a vague but not too-vague hint" is an exercise in getting into other peoples' heads, not optimizing action points - but for me, quite engaging.

Players with lots of inside jokes / knowledge / experience can make things too opaque for the other players, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Components: Perfectly beautiful cards. The expansions help to ensure the freshness of the quantity. The score track inside the box is clever, but without it the game could have fit inside a much smaller box. This game easily lends itself to being played with more people, so it would be nice if by default the game came with pieces for 8, instead of for 6.

Expanded by Odyssey, the scoretrack is much better, and the voting peg boards are much simpler to use and score. Big improvement.

Experience: Limiting the storyteller to one, terse sentence is a great way to both ensure ambiguity and ease the anxiety of those nervous playing creativity-based games. It is very much like a game version of Chris Van Allsburg's book The Mysteries of Harris Burdick. We end up telling cute little tales, and it's fun trying to determine which of the cards best matches the story or phrase. There are some times when every card seems a perfect match; and times when none of the cards seem to fit.

To make a quick contrast to Apples to Apples; in that game, I often find myself not having any good card to fit with the active description, and so I burn a particularly flat card from my hand just to get rid of it. In Dixit, every card is precious, and can be used in any number of wonderful situations. The cards each have have enough complexity that we find ourselves focusing on different aspects of the cards, and then later discussing why such-and-such card was/wasn't a good fit, and what we think is going on in the picture. Very entertaining.

One potential problem: unlike in Thingamajig or Ostrakon, in Dixit the active player doesn't care how many players pick their card, just so long as they split the group (although every player who picks someone else gives away a free point). So the active player has an incentive to construct some cryptic riddle intended to be understood by just one person at the table, which is less fun.

First Played: 2011-01-16
Last Played: 2015-01-10
Plays (5):
4 players: 1
5 players: 2
6 players: 1
7 players: 1

RATING: 6

- playing with small kids could lead to very unexpected results;
- easy to learn.
Cons:
- Not a competetive game;
- You will not manage to play it for more than one hour in a row as the process will be still tha same and nothing changes.
- After two or three plays the cards run out and assotiations start to be linked with previous sessions.  This can be avioded, however, by printing additional pics.

Result:
Could give a try if in right mood and with right company. Gameplay depends very much on the people you will be playing with.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A truly amazing game.  The creativity it invokes is potentially stunning and it's all based on two simple factors: 1) the multi-faceted art of Carduot, which lends itself remarkably well to varying interpretations; and 2) the clever mechanic of trying to get as few players as possible to guess your clue without no one getting it.

I've rated this game an 8 in the past, so why is it now lower?  Firstly, it can get repetitive.  It's common for people to want to play again immediately after the first play.  That second play almost always runs out of steam before the half-way mark and I wish the game would be over.

Secondly, it requires people who enjoy the process of creating these clues.  Non-participants can make it uninteresting.  This can also sap the energy from the game.  It's only fun if players bring a fun attitude with them.

So the rating reflects that the game has delicate play circumstances and can be reduced to boring status.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Mark

If you go in trying to win this game all serious-like, you should probably be playing something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Party game where players have to guess which is the storyteller's picture.  Played in terms where each turn a player becomes the storyteller.  They select a picture from their hand of cards, and say a sound or phrase relating to that picture.  The other players try to select a picture that best fits the storyteller's phrase.  Cards are collected, shuffled, displayed, then players select what they think the storyteller's card was.  Points are awarded based on picks, with the storyteller wanting someone to pick their card, but not everyone.  Fun game that works to a point (the right sort of game group is mandatory) - very much in the style of Barbarossa and Apples To Apples.  Not sure about longevity - probably needs to be sprinkled around different groups to keep it fresh.  Expansion is a must, I suspect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Such a great fun creative party social game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is not the type of game I usually enjoy, but it is pretty fun, interesting, and the pictures are very beautiful and intriguing.  It gets your mind working in a different way than most board games.  My only concern is how much replayability the game will have once you've seen all the pictures a few times. This will probably be one of my go-to games (along with No Thanks) when I need something simple, unintimidating, and easy to teach to non-gamers.  I appreciate that it can accommodate 6 players.

Update: For some reason, I got tired of this quite quickly.  It has no replay value for me now that the novelty wore off.  My partner is still enchanted with it though.

RATING: 8.5
BGG Secret Santa '14
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Play a card from your hand and describe it vaguely. Others also play cards from their hands that fit description. Suffle cards and then others try to guess which one is the described one.

Mechanism
Gain points by guessing others descriptions and by placing card that someone picks for a wrong answer. If your description is too easy and all quess it or too hard and none quess it only others get points.

To whom:
Partygame, social, ideas on cards are very multifaceted and good clues are hard to come by. Many clues can be found on many details.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My favourite party game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Love this game, always willing to play as the pictures are amazing
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Each player has a hand of cards featuring different pictures.  All of the pictures are beautiful, but bizarre and ambiguous.  One player uses a word, phrase, or sentence to describe one of his pictures, with the intent of describing his picture well enough that some people figure out which is the card in question, but not so well that everyone does.  It seems strange at first, but players rapidly become better at being suitably ambiguous.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
There is a genius mechanism found in the popular party game Balderdash, which asks players to try to find the correct answer among several incorrect user submitted answers. This mechanism has been imitated already several times, including this new game. However, Dixit feels completely fresh, thanks in part to its incredible artwork. It's a beautiful game that will no doubt attract even the  most casual of game players.

[b]1.5.11 Update:[/b] I continue to be horrible at this game. Always going too obscure or abstract with my clues for people to grasp. Nevertheless, I still enjoy it.

[b]Rating History:[/b]
< 1.5.11 = 8.50

RATING: N/A
Marie C. did an amazing job with the artworks on the card.

This is a storytelling game, where you're necessarily need to tell a story to describe a card. Enough with just a word or even a sound. Basically, you could tell or do anything to describe anything from your card. Telling too much will be to obvious and that's not what you want to do.

This is probably my limit to a storytelling game as that mechanic really doesn't click with me very well (maybe because I'm not good with stories).

It's a great game, extremely perfect for ice-breakers. Too bad it's only capped at six players. However, playing with more than six is really not a problem, but you will need to make a custom pieces for the voting.

I basically bought the game the next day after my first play. That's how excited I was with the game.

RATING: 6.8
The illustrations on the cards will bring you into another world. Suitable for everybody, even small children. 
It's a narration game, where one player secretly choses one of his cards and will say anything - a word, a sentence, a title of a song, a piece of music, a movie quote.... - and all the other players will pick a card from their hand that could fit what the narrator player has chosen. All the cards chosen will be shuffled, and and the players will vote trying to pick the narrator card. A little gem.

RATING: 8
Dixit is an easy game, that makes friend tells a phrase that describes some in a picture. All the others try to put a picture that has the same meaning o are relacionated (all of this in secret, because the magic is to try to guess what's the correct picture). 

Dixit is always different, you can say more than a thousand phrases for each picture, and the game can be adapted according to the friends or people you share the experience. Is a MUST HAVE if you have frequent meetings with friends (non-board game friends love it too).

About the number of players:
You need 5 or 6 friends to play it. With 3 or 4 are good, but the lack of random options gonna affect your experience.

RATING: 6.14
This is a simple but wonderful storytelling game with cards that are work of art. 
This game is great for parties or when you want to play with kids.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic party/Family game.  Select a card from your hand make a noise or quick reference based on the strange art on the cards. Everyone selects one card from their hand that closely resembles that noise or card and hands it to the active player. All cards are displayed and everyone but the active player votes. If everyone guesses the active players card the voters get points the active player gets nothing. If some get it but not everyone the active players and the voters that got it right all get points and the people that voted wrong get none. 

The art on the cards are beautiful and often stunning. Weird pictures with oddities all around make for endless expressions and endless possibilities.  A game my family is constantly voting for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I prefer this hand over fist to Apples to Apples, which I consider similar party games.  The artwork is spectacular, the strategy deeper.  Lots of fun in the right crowd, although I don't play this very often unless someone specifically asks for it.

RATING: 8

After several plays though, I'm thinking it's more about knowing your opponents, and exploiting what you know about them to target clues at them.  Like most games I love, it's all about knowing the people sitting at the table, and games like that are my jam.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players draw from a deck of full sized illustrations and decide how they want to express a particular card, before placing it face down. Everyone else picks another card that might fit the same clue and players vote on all the submissions. Extremely fun for everyone who plays, the art is just so lovely to look at in between turns. Dixit Quest fits really well with the original game, but Dixit Journey features a new artist imitating the original style, which can sometimes not quite fit with other cards. Odyssey adds a new scoring track that works much better than the original international version, although the voting pegs aren't any use at all in my opinion.

15-30m, best with 3-6 players. 25+ plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have always been told that I am a man of odd taste.  I will freely admit that I tend to enjoy what some people would consider weird.  Well, the pictures in Dixit are strange but they are beautifully drawn.  So why am I talking about pictures of a game rather than game itself? The pictures are the most integral part of the game.  

Unlike most party games, Dixit serves as a thoughtful/reflective game for creative gamers rather than social distractions such as Say Anything, Apples to Apples, etc.  Each round one person chooses one card in their hand, places it face down on the table and states a word/phrase as a clue to what card they've played.  All other players add one card from their hand facedown that they think matches the word or phrase.  The cards are shuffled and then placed in a line.  Everyone but the 'storyteller' simultaneously and secretly votes on what they think is the storyteller's card.  Points will be awarded based on who picked what cards.

The 'storyteller's' description does not want to be an exact description of what's seen in the picture or too specific a clue about what card it is.  The storyteller also does not want to state a phrase that is completely unrelated to the picture unless it's a clue the storyteller feels only one or two others may understand. The reason being is that if everyone or no one votes on the card that he submitted, he will not score anything and everyone else will score.  The only negative thing to be said about the game is that if you play this game too often the pictures will become familiar and might feel a little stale.

I will leave you with the awesomeness of Dixit:

[img]https://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic535130_md.jpg[/img]

"Blinded by me you can't see a thing"

Which one of the above cards would you think was mine if I had given the above clue?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
At work
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably my favorite party game ever. Great for all ages, and great for a mix of player types. Great to mix with bookish types, and jocks, etc... The more creative the group the better. The fact that you don't have to write things down or draw a picture encourages verbal communication.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game play is similar to [i]Apples to Apples[/i] and the scoring resembles [i]Thingamajig[/i] & [i]Cluzzle[/i] in that clues can’t be too accurate or else you won’t score any points. What makes [i]Dixit[/i] superior in this genre is the surreal artwork on the cards that is not only fun to look at but serves a practical purpose by providing a high degree of flexibility when choosing what cards to play.  "[i]Apples to Apples[/i] for adults" is a fitting description. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
One of the best party games at the moment. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dixit
Pros
--The Art!  I owned this game and regifted, but much later after the fact, I regret that I did so simply because of the art in this game.
--Very accessible non-confrontational party game.
--Encourages thinking completely unique from what any other game does.

Cons
--Ends with a whimper.  Every ending of this game has been “Oh, that’s the last round.  I guess I won, huh”. 
--Group-dependent on two criteria………… familiarity with the group can go a long way, and the group must be seeking the specific kind of experience this game offers.
--Not a game that should be played more than, say, once a year, as familiarity with the cards takes away much of the appeal.

RATING: 6
[1 play] The art in this game is mesmerizing.  It reminds me a bit of the work of Chris van Allsburg.  The art drew me to the game even though the gameplay sounded like something I might otherwise dismiss.  Finally got to play, and… it was OK.  Everyone was mostly new to the game, and I felt like it had (or potentially had) a level of play we weren't tapping.  Quite often you'd say something that seemed a hair's-breadth from blindingly obvious, and no one would have any idea what you meant.  Really the most successful technique was to make some concrete literary or pop-culture reference, and hope that someone (but not everyone) would connect with it.  But it seemed like the optimal way to play would not be that, but to approach it in a much more intuitive and creative way.  I'm not sure I am cut out for this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(Rating including expansions: [thing=145325]Origins[/thing], [thing=92828]Odyssey[/thing], [thing=119657]Dixit 3[/thing], [thing=156189]Daydreams[/thing])

Innovative party game. Easy to learn and fast to play. The only drawback is that there can be a tendency among people that know each other to give hints that outsiders at the table have a hard time to understand, e.g. "your mom's roses..." or "that time at your house when that thing broke".

Even though there are 84 unique cards in the base game and the ending condition is that you run out of cards, you will have seen almost all of them on your first play and most certainly by the second. This doesn't have to be bad necessarily because it forces you to be creative and come up with new and more subtle clues. Still, I think I'll have to get an expansion or two to increase the variety.

Dixit is best with 5 or 6 people. When playing with 4, we normally add a random card from the deck so there are 5 cards to choose from. Don't play this with 3 players, it can't be saved.

[i]Edit:[/i] The game benefits greatly from an expansion! Including one expansion, the rating improved from 9 to 10. I don't know if getting a second expansion is a must though because the box cannot fit more than one expansion inside (unless you get the one with the smaller point track) and I dislike having to the game in multiple boxes.

[i]Edit:[/i] Got Dixit Odyssey as the second expansion. The box is much better and has room for three to four expansions and comes with a new scoring board that also serves as a placeholder for the cards. Technically, you could play up to 12 people, but it's still best with 5 or 6 players. I also dislike the new way to pick your number, so I stuck with the old one. I still recommend getting Dixit Odyssey mainly for the box, the cards and the new scoring board.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

++ Great family game!

-- Not for gamers...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A sublime party game experience. The artwork is engaging, compelling, and inspiring and helps the game transcend from a run-of-the-mill party game to something more interesting and unique. I've had some great laughs playing this game as well as some moments of very worthwhile deduction. I've also been out of it from the start but still managed to enjoy myself until it was over. 

Moreover, everyone I've ever introduced it to has taken to it. For example, one of my teenage nieces started off with a dubious attitude about it (as teenagers are wont to do) but she ended up loving it. Definitely happy to have in my collection as it more than fills its particular niche; it stands out in it.

A Favorite Dixit Story: The clue was "bad idea" and the card was the snail at the bottom of some winding stairs. Afterwards, I asked my friend how the clue and the card matched up, and he said with great earnestness, "It's a snail thinking about going up some stairs.  That's a bad idea!"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If I'm just hanging out and drinking, I generally prefer to do something more active like throw glow in the dark bocci. Or just throw rocks. But, if I'm going to sit down and play a game, I can handle this one because 1) it's relatively easy to push bunnies while drunk and 2) I don't have to read words to play.

Like a visual/imagination-based version of the Dictionary game, this game is simple and plays quickly. It requires that you calibrate the clues you give based on the other players so I find this a highly interactive game, even if the way you engage other players is often nonverbal.

Light party games aren't a genre I'm usually fond of, but this is a great game for people who like: imagination, trippy illustrations, or intuiting the intentions of other players in subtle clues.

RATING: 9
A Dixit hatalmas erénye, hogy véleményem szerint (meg az eladott darabok szerint is) több emberrel szerettette meg a társasjátékozást, mint bármely másik játék! Ezt az érdemet pedig nem lehet elvenni tőle! Valóban egyszerű, és élvezetes asszociációs játék! Elsősorban családi, nem pedig partijáték, ezt a címet az Odyssey birtokolja! A Dixit nagy erénye még, hogy tényleg bárhol, bármikor, bárkinél bevethető! Én is bármikor kapható vagyok egy partira; így volt ez régen is, mikor csak egy két játékot ismertem. És van ez most, amikor bővülnek a társasos ismereteim, és a játékaim száma!

RATING: 7
Played at BayCon2012.  

If you end up in a game where a player cannot give very good clues and so their card is obvious, this game really suffers.

On the down side (maybe) my boyfriend is more insync with his friend than with me. :(

After more plays this is growing on me a little. Whilst the game still suffers if one player is obvious, there are more descriptive words that you can apply the more you have played, there is a generational gap however as I mainly gaming group consists of us oldies and a group of 18 year old's who occasionally reference cartoons they watched whilst growing up that we oldies have never heard of. The look of confusion on their faces when they explain the clue and you still don't get it is quite amusing :)

RATING: 8
My partner's favorite game and one that has never failed to please, no matter who we introduce it to. Easily one of the more interesting and beautiful light games to have come out in the past few years. Worth getting all of the expansions, since we'll be playing it for years to come. The scoring can be a little wonky for many players, so the game benefits from one person who understands it to do the accounting. Play it with the right group of people and it can be genuinely competitive, but otherwise it's just a fun activity, and that's OK.

RATING: 9
What I love most about this game (other than the wonderful art!) is the simple rules and their flexibility. "Take this card and say anything you want" is just great for introducing a game to non-gamers.

I can see the game wearing out with repeated plays (in the same group) because there aren't an unlimited number of cards. However this is not enough of an issue for me to drag down the rating.

Update: Having played this quite a lot now, I am suprised to report that replayability is way higher than I thought. As the skill of players increase, hints have to be more subtle. Amazing.
Also, both my non-gaming mother and my non-gaming in-laws have all requested that I bring this game along. They've never done anything like that before!

RATING: 8.5
The only party game I truly enjoy

Pros
-Gorgeous artwork that invokes creativity
-The artwork makes it hard to guess which person put out which card and which card belongs to which clue
-Can be less dependent on specific cultural references
-I like the freedom the game gives people to just give any clue (can be an action, a phrase, a word etc)

Con
-Somewhat low replayability value within the same group
-Limited number of cards in a single set (you will likely see all cards within 1-3 play through).
-Depending on group, may be dependent on knowledge of pop culture

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.6
No jogo, um jogador diz uma palavra relacionada a carta que joga, fechada, e todos os outros jogadores deve jogar um carta, fechada, relacionada com a palavra. Em seguida, embaralha-se, vira-se e cada jogador escolhe a carta que acha que é a carta relacionada a palavra dita pelo jogador da vez. A palavra que você diz não pode ser obvia nem pode ser difícil pois, se todos ou nenhum jogador acertarem sua carta, você não ganhará pontos.
Hiper introdutório. É para brincar com novatos ou veteranos que tem muita paciência.
5.8
--------------
Quanto mais jogo mais chato acho.
5.6
--------------
Comprei o jogo. Vou baixar a nota mais um pouco :)
5.4
--------------
Até que a partida foi divertida.
5.6

RATING: 6
I think I understand why people turns crazy about this game... Yes, it's beautiful, it's innocent, and is so-so-easy and so-so-pretty... moreover, it's fast paced and its playing time is arround 20-30 minutes.
Over those reasons, what I really appreciate on this game are its creativity and fantasy aspects; yeah, I love to construct enigmatic or poetic sentences, adding a drop of malice here and a drop of clown-ness there... But, even then, I could never give this game a rating over 7, 'cause to me it'll always belong to the group of "party games", or "childhood games" (nothing against children and/or parties... Just not an engaging experience for me).

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a party game. It is, however, not of the rowdy kind. Basically it's an association game where players try to figure out which of a number of images was the one described by the active player who wants people to find him out, but not all of them.

Pretty much all of the game depends on the images which most people seem to be enamoured with but a few also detest. The images probably are the biggest asset of the game but they are also a liability because there aren't that many of them, and unless you play with a different bunch of people all the time I do not expect them to last very long. Once a certain state of hivemind has set in you'll need new cards for the game to stay fresh.

Dixit is certainly no bad candidate for the SdJ award. What it does it does very well, and its visual quality makes it easy to hook non-gamers, too. Myself, I prefer the non-visual approach of Linq that also promises better replayability but I suppose that's mostly because I am not much of a visual person in the first place.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game.  It has worked with all types of groups and ages.  Even got some non-gamer relatives to get into it.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Good party game. Appeals to the creative, imaginative side of the players. I think there may be a problem if only part of a game group is familiar with the images (which should start being the case after only a few games). Or maybe if a part of the group know each other a lot better than the others, which could lead them to use otherwise undecipherable private jokes and such. Good sportsmanship will avoid that but it's a little drawback of the game as it is. But the game is still good fun and a nice icebreaker too. Exactly the right thing for the few remaining people after a party ended or for a quick game of something before going to bed. It's quick to learn, quick to play, and everybody usually likes it. Plus the images ae beautiful.

RATING: 6
Enjoyed this with 2 other players. You rotate being the story teller while everyone else lays down a card they think best matches the story. Points are scored based on your guesses. Even if you're not the story teller and someone guessed it to be your card, you get a some points for that. You get even more points if you guess the actual card the story teller set down. The nice thing about this game is even though it is player pitted against player, there is no direct attacks but plenty of player interaction.

- the game is simple and easy to teach.

Cons:

- it can suffer from analysis-paralysis.
- to be fair, it is that kind of game where winning does not matter much - so why such a convoluted scoring..

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
  The game starts with everyone having a hand of cards with interesting pictures on them.  The "active player" puts places a card face down and describes it briefly.  All of the other players try to choose a card to match that description.  Then the cards are shuffled and the "non-active" players secretly guess which picture was the "active player's."  The goal is to provide a description vague enough to allow multiple interpretations but still allow the players to guess the right card.
  This is a pretty quick party game.  It has never gone over half and hour.  It is extremely easy to teach, but better to play with those you know well.  The more experience a player is the tighter the games become, though this can never really be a competitive game.
  Players who have seen the cards before have a distinct advantage, this is easily remedied with a "practice game."  If a player gets a lead in the beginning of the game, they tend to stay there.  Players left behind, tend to not move much.  Also, this game is pretty terrible with anything less than four players.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very fun game. This game works like Apples to Apples, only we find it to be much more interesting. The cards are all art.  In the game, one person will take a card and come up with a caption to match the art, and the other players each come up with a card that is a lot like the main card. Then the person who made up the caption collects all the cards and puts the cards out, each under one number in 1-6. Then the other players each vote on which one they think the real one is.

RATING: 8
Excellent party game for all ages. One player describes the picture on one of his cards, each other player selects one of their cards that may possibly fit the description, all these cards are layed out and the other players try to identify the original card. Promotes language and imagination - your descriptions need to be suitibly precise and sufficiently vague to maximise your scoring. Nice art (whimsical and mystical) and good quality cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Quite good in its category. The gameplay is a pleasant experience, the winning isn't so important. The strategy is always the same. As the storyteller you should make up something that a few (one would be the best) players will guess (if all or nobody guesses it's not good, because the storyteller gets no points). When you are not the storyteller, just put a card that best mathes what the storyteller said. The rest (how many points players will get) depends strongly on the cards you get and on guessing of other players.
So it's rather a social experience than a serious game. And you shouldn't play Dixit too often. Otherwise you will soon be fed up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit is kind of like a cross between Apples to Apples (meh) and Thingamajig (woot!), but the target you're trying to match is an image instead of a word.

The fantastical, childlike art is the key to the game's success. It stimulates the imagination, and is sufficiently ambiguous to offer several possible approaches for the sentence clues.

I bought this game for my sister and brother-in-law, and they keep telling me how huge a hit it has been with all their different groups of friends (some of which are avid game players, but not all). Personally, I've only played it once so far. I enjoyed the experience, and would like to play more.

Rating is likely to rise.

[UPDATE] I did bump my rating up a point. Personally, there are a bunch of party games I'd rather play than Dixit (although I do enjoy it). But Dixit has an amazing success rate with all sorts of mixed groups, and it always seems to stimulate interesting conversation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love the simplicity of this game and it's quirky art style.
It's French!  And it shows, but in a good way.

Playing it get's people interested in trying to discern how you think, and how best to connect the images on the cards to shared experiences you've had. It is at once, the best and worst thing about the game. 
If you play with people you don't know, then you can't possibly understand their weird little references, unless they are being totally obvious, which this game punishes. If, however, you play with someone you know very well, then you two will likely dominate the game and leave other players feeling left out. 
It's a great game for the RIGHT GROUP, but otherwise, it may fall flat.
I'd recommend picking up one or two expansions, just so you have more cards. 
After you've seen the one with a living purse, complete with teeth and googly eyes, regurgitating it's contents on the floor in gleeful delight- well, you just can't un-see that. It also doesn't help that the images tend to stick in your mind, and after a few plays, the game can grow stale with the same group playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like this game, but it doesn't make it to the table as much as other games do for some reason.

RATING: 10

RATING: 7
This is a great game to play with family and non-gamer friends. I like the fact that it engages a different part of my brain than most board games. It's a lot of fun trying to figure out how many layers of abstraction are required to target just a subset of the other players. It's very satisfying when someone understands a well-disguised reference, and it's funny explaining my thought process when my story flops.

RATING: 9
There are tons of people who HATE games who will LOVE playing this, and if you bring your thinking caps there's really nothing like a round of Dixit.

If you keep score, don't use the scoring track in the box; poker chips or spare change is much better.  And don't limit yourselves to 6 players--just have everyone use 8-, 10-, 12-, or 20-sided dice to indicate their choices if you have a huge group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3

I don't like to do this, but Mysterium has knocked dixit down a peg for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Really nice cards and a nice idea of associating vague descriptions make a boring game. The huge problem is that the idea is enforced with a terribly simple scoring mechanism that is heavily dependent on the number of players. Another big problem is that the initial impact of the nice game idea turns out to be unbelievably ephemeral. The first couple of rounds of my first game I thought "what a nice idea", but before the end of the first play I was already bored with the way it was executed. This one became "Spiel des Jahres 2010" for the potential of an idea that is just not fleshed out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ezért szeretem: még a legelső társasjátékok között próbáltam ki és azonnal megfogott (gondolom sok embernél az első játékaik mindig is közel állnak a szívükhöz). Szeretem az asszociációs játékokat és a nyuszibábuk is szimpatikusak voltak. Több órán át játszottunk, mégsem untam meg (ebben szerepe volt játékostársaimnak is). Nem volt kérdés, hogy magunknak is beszerzem. Könnyű tanítani, fiataltól az idősig megmozgatja az emberek fantáziáját. Gyors játékmenet, így akinek nem tetszik, „fájdalom” nélkül ki tud szállni az első játék után. Mind bevezető, mind levezető játéknak ideális. Mindenképpen játszunk több fordulót, mert az elsőben még csikoroghatnak az agyban a „fogaskerekek”.
Kinek ajánlanám: nem tudok olyat mondani, akinek nem ajánlanám. Viszont nem is erőltetném senkire.
A kiegészítőkről: ugyanannak a csapatnak több játék után már nehéz újat mondani, mesélni. Ezen szerencsésen segítenek a kiegészítők, beszerzésük ajánlott. Ha van idő, kedv és kreativitás, saját pakli is készíthető pl.: mesékből gyerekeknek, festményekből, …
Házi szabályok: ha a játék egy adott téma köré épül fel pl.: karácsony, Lovecraft, fantasy, … megnehezíti a játékot, de ugyanennyit javulni is tud a játékélmény, néha sírva röhögés a kényszer szülte megoldásokon. Ugyanez igaz, ha csak énekelni, mutogatni, vagy rajzolni lehet Activity módra.

RATING: 7
Yera, Regalo de D.A 2015

Con expansiones. tengo que mirar cuales exactamente. 

Es un juego de deduccion con cartas de dibujo abstracto. hay que adivinar la que ha puesto cada jugador siguiendo una tematica, pero añadiendo una carta propia intentando confundir a los otros jugadores para que elijan la nuestra y no la del jugador que propuso la tematica. 

es un juego ideal para gente muy imaginativa (tal vez hasta demasiado xD) y sobre todo para todo tipo de publico. ideal para jugar con niños. ademas, es muy rejugable. 

Para ciertos tipos de jugadores algo introspectivos y poco dados a la onirica puede ser un juego complicado. lo jugaran pero no lo buscaran con asiduidad y tenderan a quedarse atras en la clasificacion de la partida mas pronto que tarde. 

Un buen detalle del juego es que regula su duracion lo justo para no hacerse excesivamente pesado. 80 cartas para 4 jugadores son 20 rondas y ya queda en el limite de empezar a hacerse demasiado largo.
