RATING: 8
What a beautiful game! The illustrations are wonderful and I really like the gameplay as well. It was described to me as Barbarossa meets Apples to Apples and that's pretty accurate. I'd prefer this to either one of those though. Very accessible and fun. I'm not sure of the replayability, because it would be tempting to use the same clues you have before. In a game where you see every card each game, this seems it could be problematic. Even so, I'm withholding judgement on that aspect for the time being.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit is the penultimate family and friends game of clever deduction and creative response. In other words, this is the game that Apples to Apples wanted to be (or Cards Against Humanity, it's 'older' and cruder sibling) in that there is actually a scoring mechanic that keeps everyone involved the whole way through.

In my opinion, it's accessible enough for usual non-gamers to jump in while also being gamey enough to provide enough incentive for everyone but all-too-serious gamers to play.

Also, the art is beautiful and provides many different possibilities for title-jamming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun as a party game, and it has been popular towards the end of a long gaming night, after finishing the heavier games. You learn the game in a couple of minutes, and it challenges your creativity and imagination - a welcome departure from the heavier economic games and Train games we usually play. You have to play this for the pure fun of it - 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

But all in all a very innovative and diffrent game.

RATING: 7
Familiar idea, presented in an intriguingly different way. Don't let the comparisons to Apples to Apples turn you off-- it's much better! This game requires true creativity, and abstract thinking is a must. The art is weirdly charming and evocative. The first play, I had a lot of fun with it, but with only 80-some cards I can't imagine it has much replay value. Glad I eventually got to try this.

RATING: 8

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I previously rated this game as a 2... but I've changed that decision to a 7. What changed? Mainly the way my group and I were playing it. We tried to game the situation by telling the "story" that would provide the most points.

It kept getting requested, and I then realized that the game is actually about telling the story, that the pure enjoyment comes from telling the story, and the points or who wins does not nearly matter as much.

Once you can tell a cohesive story that's actually a minute long, and you can really role-play it out in a narrative manner like some sort of open reading book club, the game becomes exciting for everyone. Even when I started making really detailed stories though, some people didn't bother and still didn't see the game my way (sucks for them). They continued to make stories that suck.

Dixit. Your mileage may vary on this one, and it ultimately depends on the players, not the game.

I give it a 7, because some players suck at this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

PL: Nie rozumiem fenomenu tej gry, jej zasad, i kto decyduje czy skojarzenie było ok, czy nie. Przy dość przejrzystych hasłach, gracze są w stanie bez problemu wybrać moją kartę. Przy mniej oczywistych istnieje szansa, że nie zrozumieją o co mi chodziło. Nie sprawiła mi przyjemności, rozgrzała moje zwoje mózgowe do czerwoności, powodując dymienie z uszu. Raczej nie polecam.

EN: I do not understand the phenomenon of the game, its rules, and who decides whether the association was ok or not. With quite clear associations, players are able to easily point at my card. With less obvious there is a chance that you will not understand what I meant. Playing it was far from pleasuring, it warmed my brain to red coils, causing the smoke from my ears. I would not recommend, and I wish I won't play it again.

RATING: 8
[i]The only way to truly win this game is to get the anchor and the sad clown in the same tableau.[/i]

UPDATE:  Genius, like a mime dangling whimsically from a sateen ribbon.  I absolutely [i]love[/i] the open-ended nature of the Storyteller's role—your "clue" can be [i]anything[/i]:  a word, phrase, sentence or full-blown tale; a poem, song, or hummed tune; or even just sound effects, hand gestures and/or facial expressions!  Boring people kill this game, causing it to slump and die of ennui.  Only sideways-thinking, risk-taking entertainers need apply.

I will play this at the drop of a beret.

Also in the box:

[gameid=55660]
[gameid=121288]

RATING: 6.5
Bought as a family game for Christmas.  Played once and it worked, but I was underwhelmed.  We are big Balderdash fans and it was a bit like playing that but with far fewer opportunities for humour.  It's almost like an attempt to "euroise" balderdash by removing the need for language and writing!  The artwork is nice.

One other personal opinion: I wouldn't waste valuable "geek" gaming time playing this (or Balderdash) simply because I get far too little time to play "proper" games!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
I think it's brilliant that it draws on people's creativity and abstract thinking and there is near to no luck in it which appeals to me personally a lot.  However, I found that playing with people from different cultural backgrounds or even when two individuals in the party know each other very well adds a significant degree of dis- or advantage to it that cannot be undone.

Therefore, I'm very glad and grateful I played this game but do not recommend it to anybody but board game parties that know each other all to a very similar degree - in that particular situation I can see this game to go off (like a house on fire).  In all other situation it has next to no replay value as the outcome is clear before the start (e.g. individuals that know each other and the game well will aways outplay others)!

RATING: 8
Nagyszerű parti játék. Egyszerű ötletből, egyszerű játékmenet, mégis megfelelő társasággal nagyon jól tud működni. Ennek a játéknak a lényegét a társaság adja, maga a játék, illetve a kártyák a játékban csak a körítés, amit a társaság tagjainak mondásai, beszólásai töltenek ki. Szóval ha valakinek nem jön be a játék, nem a játék tehet, hanem a megfelelő társaság hiánya. 

Egy idő után persze unalmas, mert ha ugyanazok a kártyák kerülnek elő hajlamos az ember ugyanazt mondani róla. Ezen némileg segítenek az új kártyák.

RATING: 7
As a sucker for themes, I had high hopes for Dixit. 

I can't say I loved it. The cards are beautiful, but they're memorized quickly. Unless you're with a group you know very well, you can't make the references that you want to. 

I'd be interested to know if the game is better with the expansions, but as is I think I'd only whip it out if we needed to mix things up after too many rounds of love letter or Tsuro.

UPDATE: I played Dixit with a friend who asked us each time why we chose the cards we chose. The game was MUCH more enjoyable when each player started explaining their choices in card and in clue. I'd recommend making this a house rule! It's a lot more fun that way.

RATING: 6
A simple communicating game that involves describing a picture with sufficient ambiguity to leave doubt as to which picture from a group is the one referred to. RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great, great party (or any other time) game.  Has superficial similarities to Apples to Apples, but Dixit replaces the arbitrary nature of A2A with genuine creative skill.  Unique in the type of creative thinking it requires - even though there is no deep strategy, I still feel a great sense of accomplishment from coming up with a particularly good clue.  If I had to nitpick I would say that the scoring mechanism is problematic as it's easy to have a runaway leader, but scoring is almost beside the point in Dixit.  I can see this becoming a go-to party game in the future.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A wonderful abstract party game where knowing how the other players think is a great advantage.

Dixit is a card game consisting of many surreal illustrated cards. Players take turns being "it". The player who is "it" must choose a mystery card from their hand and describe it. The player may be as descriptive or vague as they wish. All other players secretly submit a card that matches the description as closely as possible. The cards are mixed and voted on. The goal is for the player who is "it" to get some but *not* all of the other players to vote for their card. The goal of all other players is to guess the right card while hoping that the other players guess the one that they submitted (for both will get them points). Then the play continues.

Much of the game's brilliance is in figuring out how to describe the wonderfully complex and surreal cards in such a way that not everyone will be able to guess. It helps to know those that you're playing with and how they think.

I love this game and look forward to getting other Dixit titles. I recommend it for game nights with family or good friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A fun version of Apples to Apples.

We plan to use the cards in order to create creative stories with our daughter once she grows up a bit. I recommend this as a family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is barely a game, but offers the potential for a fun social experience. The heart of Dixit is the cards, which are attractively illustrated and carefully designed for their purpose. The rules included with Dixit are simple enough for a 6-year-old to understand, but somewhat frustrating for an experienced gamer like myself - when you vote for the storyteller's card then picking randomly will gain you an average of more than one point per turn. However, the official rules can easily be replaced by others of your own devising. The board is superfluous - Dixit should really have been published in a small box with just the cards and scoring markers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
:thumbsup: fantastic illustrations

The optimal strategy is to either give a targeted inside-reference to a friend, or give a random clue that has nothing to do with the card you play, so that it's impossible for [i]all[/i] of your opponents to choose your card. To counter this, your opponents' best play is to do the same thing, effectively making Dixit completely broken or random. Is this strategy against the "spirit of the game?" I don't care. Any rules implemented to disable this strategy are unenforceable.

The cards in this game could be used for an interesting variant of Codenames: Pictures

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit is one of my favorite party games. It follows the Apples to Apples mechanic of having a rotating judge that chooses a phrase, sound or concept to get cards in response. The main difference of this game is it's absolute beauty. The art on the Dixit cards are beautiful and inspire creative ideas. This game always gets laughs from my family and gaming group. While this probably my 2nd favorite party game, it definitely sees the table more than any other party game I own. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Funny to observe two kinds of people: these making simple connections between picture and description and those making non-obvious ones and/or requring knowledge of culture/word juggling abilities :-)

The mechanics resembles Barbarossa to some point (create something not too difficult and not too easy to guess).
All in all - fun and lots of laughter, but I've got some concerns about the replayability...

EDIT: I don't recommend 6-player mode --> too much of accident and luck.

SOLD (serious replayability issue).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a storytelling game about mimicry.  A "storyteller" gives a description about a picture, simultaneously trying to score points themselves while limiting the points other players earn.  The beautiful art and scoring conditions reward players for clever thinking and creative wordplay.  Dixit won't connect with everyone but those that do will never forget it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Overall it is basically Balderdash but with cards and a good gateway or family game for sure.

RATING: 8.5
I love this game. It was the first modern board game I bought along with love letters and I don't regret it for a minute. The beauty of this game is its accessibility and the way it changes depending upon who you play it with. (I was totally thrashed by a group of 9 years old and under). The artwork is also absolutely stunning. Over time it begins to lose its novelty and many of the 'stories' begin to get repeated but expansions should help mitigate this. It can become somewhat repetitive if played persistently but the creativity and accessibility of this game makes it one of my go to gateway games and an all time favourite.

RATING: 9
A nearly perfect game - my possible only complaints are that the box does have compartments to separate the cards from the voting tokens, that the player pieces aren't more stable and that there aren't more of those beautiful cards.

The mechanics and scoring are so elegantly designed that it makes it nearly impossible to cheat (let people know which card is yours and get 0 points). Playing it multiple times, with the same people, just forces you to be more cryptic each time (maybe a downside for some).

RATING: 8.5
2011-07-07

Initial Rating: 5.5 (April 2010)

AWESOME game. Once upon a time I though I wasn’t a party gamer and I thought all party games sucked (due to Apples to Apples that, incidentally, sucks big time). Enter Dixit to my life and what a game it is. It is perfect for gamers and non gamers, easy to teach, short play time and guaranteed fun.

Dixit is the game that made me a party gamer as well, without it I would have not played Time´s Up, Curses and so many other great games, it opened a new whole world for me. 

Try it and you won’t be disappointed. Great GREAT game.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2014-09-29

Dixit was one of the first boardgames I ever played and today, almost 4 years later, I still love the game. I never say no to a game of Dixit and I always enjoy it. When I get around to do my list of favorite party games, I’m pretty sure Dixit will be in the top three.

Gorgeous art with high depth. Every time I play I notice new things on the cards. Fast playtime, easy to teach, lots of fun. Best with 6 players. It is a blast to see why the storyteller chose his card. Love that the game scoring is not subjective, otherwise I would hate the game. Everyone has fun even if they lost the game.

I don’t have anything bad to say about Dixit, perhaps that after a while some patterns begin to emerge so when you have the same card you think/say the same clues. To avoid this:

1. I Bought a lot of expansions (and will continue to buy everything they release for the game).

2. I play with categories (movies, boardgames, books, etc.) that keeps the game fresh.

Bottom line, a GREAT party game that will be always in my game collection. Most friends also like it.

One of 2008´s favorites. 

Current Rating: 8.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Core mechanic is based on a little-known game called thingamajig where the goal was to get some but not all people to guess your secret word.  Here the goal is to get some but not all players to guess your card based on a clue you provide. The cards are amazingly creative.  Super fun family/party game. Easy to teach. Fun to play. Always different. Expansions continue to add tons of variety.

RATING: 7
Simple game in the Apples to Apples/Balderdash party vein where the players try to deduce/guess which card best matches the lead player's (hopefully) cryptic description. 

Although the strikingly beautiful art (could a game be any more French?) and clever scoring make it one of the best of its type, I suspect the game may become a little stale without regular refreshing of the card deck. Could be a licence to print more cards (and hence money) for the publisher, especially given its multiple prize winning status!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What really needs to be said about this game that other billions of reviews haven't covered already?

Admittedly, when I played this game out at first, I saw that our group struggled a little to grasp the concept that you want to be vague, yet not too abstract that nobody will pick yours. Sometimes we gave a clue so precise that it was way too obvious. But after many plays, we started to get into Dixit-mind, and treated it like a fun party game that it was.

There are moments where you don't even care about points, but just pick a funny card, and come up with funny clue to say to get the laughter. And this moment is when this game shines brightest. 

Yes, it felt like Apples to Apples, Cards against Humanity, or Say Anything, but Dixit's artwork is just unbeat-able. We were all stunned and discussed after we played cards, looking at arts. It constantly made us go, 'wow, look at this...how do you come up with this?'

This is a very solid party game for sure. And that cultivating abstract-mind was fantastic. However, it did take some time to click into that mind-set - and there maybe some people who will be turn off from this kind of game from being shy, or just cannot think of witty jokes. If so, I would shy away from this and go with Apples to Apples where answers are already given.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit consists of a deck of cards featuring some very surreal artwork. Everyone is dealt a hand of six cards. One person starts out as the "storyteller" who picks one card out of their hand and says a sentence related to it. The sentence can be a word or two, a full sentence, a sound, a song line, a movie title - basically anything that can be spoken. Everyone picks a card out of their hand that they think also matches the sentence. The storyteller takes these cards without looking, shuffles them up and lays them out on the table. Players then vote on which card is the storyteller's. The storyteller gets points if some, but not all, players pick his card and other players get points for picking the storyteller's card or by having other players pick their card over the storyteller's. So basically, the sentence needs to be suggestive enough to have some people pick your card, but not all. Good table talk and a bit of creative thinking a good game makes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A beautiful game and probably the most played at Christmas with the family. Very easy to teach. No strategy involved so anyone can win and always raises a giggle.

RATING: 7
A French party game. If that's not enough to get you interested I don't know what will.

Although very few rules, it's quite a tricky game. You have six cards in your hand, all with paintings on them. You need to say something about the card so that at least one of the other players can identify your card, but you don't want everyone to get it. (No points if everyone or no-one get's it)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One player is the story teller and says a word, phrase or sentence about a picture on one of his cards. The other players also each play a card based on what was said. The story teller does not get points if all or none of the other players guess the story teller's card, but the other players score 2. So the goal is to be vague when giving the description, but not too much. When only some players guess correctly they and the story teller get 3 points. Other players receiving guesses on their cards get 1 point. The art on the cards is very creative and allows for some fun and interesting descriptions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very unique game with very enjoyable artwork.  It's fairly similar to games like Apples to Apples, Attribute, Say Anything, but has a creative element similar to Cluzzle where you try to be not too obvious.  I like that you don't have to be really creative, like in Why Did the Chicken?, which I can't play at all, just a little.

This is prone to a little bit of abuse, such as using inside jokes or information that only a select person would know, so playing with spouses might irk some people that don't know what meal a husband and wife ate for their 3rd anniversary.

Also, the limited number of cards mean that you kind of have to keep trying to do different things.  An expansion would be good.  Bring on Dixit 2!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The art is great, of course, and the game fixes one of the biggest flaws of Beyond Balderdash, that of having to feign ignorance of your own contributions even when the game is going well and people are laughing out loud at each other's spots of weirdness. There are also possible pitfalls and replayability concerns here: notably the game will break down if hints are given that target specific players (by referencing previous games, common experiences or common areas of knowledge). The social payload of Dixit lies in the reveal of the reasoning behind a tricky clue, and it remains to be seen if this can reach the same heights as a truly wacked-out explanation in BB; for now I'll happily play and find out.

Thrifted on 26/3 2015.

I can't think of a more ideal party game than Dixit.  It prompts thoughtful conversation and uproarious laughter in equal parts.  The card are gorgeous, and the game is constructed so that there isn't a conflict between "best winning strategy" and "most fun strategy".

The only negative thing I can think of is that after one game, you've seen all the cards.  Fortunately, there are expansions, and also the illustrations are elaborate enough that the same card can be used in many, many different ways.

RATING: 5
I am not sure how I feel about Dixit.  I thought it would go over very well with the family, but it fell really flat.  Even my wife didn't like it, which surprised me.   

It reminds me a lot of Apples to Apples.  There is more thought and strategy in Dixit than A2A, which you would think would make it better but it makes it less fun.  In other words, I feel like Dixit is a party game trying to mask itself as a strategy game.  If you play A2A, you know it's just a party game and you don't worry about trying to have a strategy you just play to fun (not caring if you win or lose).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Absolutely enchanting! There are very, very few party games I enjoy or games that are this light, but this is a winner!

This game is simply gorgeous. The art is delightful--whimsical, dream-like, surreal, vibrant, and charmingly amateur (in a good way--it has child-like wonder and expressiveness that really goes well with the simplified figures and forms). They are abstract-ish enough that a good many "stories" could be told based on their imagery.

The scoring is simple here but nicely considered. In similar games (like Apples to Apples, or Loaded Questions), play often degenerates into senselessness when players begin to match the oddest things or make up answers quite unlike what they may normally say to "sabotage" each other. In Dixit, you can neither be too abstract nor too specific; all or no votes for your story, phrase, or word results in 0 points, forcing you to strike a nice balance.

As someone in a creative industry, I really appreciate this game. That said, you need the appropriate people to enjoy this one, people with imagination and adequate articulation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

:star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (20 plays April 2014)
This is a mind reading game finding out which one was the card the current player picked. The illustration on each card looks like telling us some sort of mystic and curious stories. It is great fun to see how people interpret the same illustration in different ways but yet sometimes they think the exactly the same thing. This is a great family game that can be played by any one for any occasion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Includes the Expansions:
Dixit 2 (Asmodee English edition) (2011)

Dixit is a family game of deduction and surreal imagery. The cards are large and beautifully done, with vibrant colors and fascinatingly evocative paintings on them. Gameplay is more relaxed and slow, because player interaction only takes place in each player's head as they try to figure out which card was played by the storyteller. Keeping score is a bit of a chore, because everyone has a chance to score points on every turn. I hoped it would be a worthy addition to family game night, but I have a major gripe with the gameplay, which seems to depend more upon "insider knowledge" than skillful play. This is a deal-breaker, because shared associations can be played to, completely unbalancing the game. Also, having the score track as a part of the game box is just bad design. This is a card game, after all; I shouldn't have to keep the box on the table while I play. Overall, I had high hopes for it because of the gorgeous art, but Dixit was a disappointment for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The comparison of this game to "Apples to Apples" is not appropriate.  In apples to apples, the "storyteller" arbitrarily decides upon a "winner".  In this game, there is no one judge, each player does the best and the score is determined objectively.  That is all the difference in the world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
3-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit is a great party game were the key skills are creativity and deduction. The game is fun, original and extremely easy to teach, so if you want a different party game that requires a reduced number of players this might be it.

Each round a player comes up with a phrase and, secretly, selects one of the beautifully illustrated cards. Then the rest of the players also add a card each, face down, and they are shuffled all together. The objective is to guess which card was picked by the first player. You get points for guessing correctly, and also for each player that you managed to bluff with your card.

I know a lot of people who have tried it and they all enjoyed it, with varying degrees of success (some actively ask to play it, others just do not mind when it hits the table). If you are looking for a party game and this one has caught your eye you should undoubtedly give it a try.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fun game in the vein of Apples to Apples or Balderdash, but with pictures. Players take turns picking a word or phrase that fits one of their cards, and then other players play cards they think fit the word or phrase in the hopes of gathering votes for their choice while trying to find the active player's card in the mix. The artwork on the cards is whimsical and fun, and the cards are a nice large size that are great to hold and to view said artwork. The box comes with room to fit three expansions in addition to the original cards, board, and tokens. The score tracking board has more artwork in addition to a brief run-down of scoring as a helpful reminder, with numbers along one side to line up cards for voting. The score tokens are nice wooden bunnies, while the voting tokens are a thick chipboard color-matched to the score tokens. Overall the game is well-designed and replayable, especially once you add in expansion sets for more art options.

RATING: 3
[size=12][b]Top 300 or higher board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Dixit:[/b][/size]
- I dislike the group consensus mechanic in games
- I think that the game lacks meaningful decisions. The best choice is often obvious so the game is primarily revolved around random card draws. 
- The game can be flawed if outside of the game clues are used. Such clues are akin to texting a player the answer  while the other players fall behind

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Not willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 7
for seasoned boardgamers Dixit is something of a curiosity - but not in a negative sense. this game requires out-of-the-box thinking, which is excellent, however not every gaming group is suitable for this kind of play. works best with people, who have a lot of common associations. on the downside, there's a limited number of cards, so after several plays, it's hard to come up with new interesting ideas. but artwork is brilliant!

RATING: 2
Dixit is Apples to Apples made worse. I hate Apples to Apples for its complete arbitrariness; the way players with a mental "link" can throw the game; how turns don't build upon each other, so there's zero strategy. Dixit takes all those bad elements from Apples to Apples and makes it worse by replacing the words with pictures. These are TERRIBLE pictures. They're nice fantasy drawings, but in terms of actually inspiring clues, they're nonstarters. I've played this once with three other people and my spouse and I both found it miserable.

RATING: 8
Everyone I've played with enjoys this game, even the occasional "I don't really like boardgames" player.  Easy to start even with those unfamiliar with the game.  Rules of play are simple to understand, although scoring is just slightly tricky for new players to pick up.  All players stay engaged with the game full time, regardless of whose turn it is.  Not much strategy to this one, and there's no backstabbing, or screwing anyone over, even though it's a competitive game.  No one seems to care too much who wins; it's just a fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like "Apples to Apples with pictures," sure, but it is made more interesting partly because of the scoring - you need your clues to be understood enough for one person to guess your card, but not so easy that everyone guesses your card. The scoring also prevents the descent into complete random absurdity that Apples to Apples devolves into (which may seem surprising given Dixit's Surrealist art, but nonetheless true).  The artwork is great, and often bizarre, and conversation is likely to revolve around some of the interesting cards.

All that said, I've gotten burnt out on the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One player is the storyteller for the turn and looks at the images on the 6 cards in her hand. From one of these, she makes up a sentence and says it out loud (without showing the card to the other players).

Each other player selects the card in their hands which best matches the sentence and gives the selected card to the storyteller, without showing it to the others.

The storyteller shuffles her card with all the received cards. All pictures are shown face up and every player has to bet upon which picture was the storyteller's.

RATING: N/A
Utilize elaborate riddles; forbid lazy one-word clues!

An excellent mind game with fantastic, surreal art. Very light, but very psychological—you must utilize the correct dose of subtlety, and think like the other players to win.

Not at all similar to most of the other card-voting party games that people compare it to, because those games don't require creativity, subtlety, or . . . well, much of anything. You're just setting down a card with a word on it, hoping that the active player will find it relevant or funny. Dixit often involves getting into the minds of ALL the other players at once, and finding new and innovative ways to interpret the details within the artwork. And while similar-ish games can be quite funny, playing Dixit with a clever group has made me laugh out loud way more often than, say, Apples to Apples has. So even that aspect of other card-voting games often falls short in comparison.

My favorite house rule for Dixit is to prohibit one-word/one-entity clues. Such clues are typically lazy or unimaginative. Obscure and esoteric riddles, stories, analogies, allusions, etc. are infinitely more fun and interesting. And there's a lot more room for a strategy there (more ways to shape your clues so that they're only understood by the people in last place, thus undermining your biggest competition while scoring maximum points). Of course, that's if you're trying to win. The game can also be fun when you're not really trying to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Alle Spieler erhalten Karten mit wunderschönen Illustrationen (meist sehr abstrus). Wer an der Reihe ist legt eine seiner Handkarten in die Mitte und sagt etwas dazu. Alle anderen Spieler legen nun ihrerseits eine in die Mitte, die zum gesagten passt. -> Mischen aufdecken -> alle Spieler raten welche Karte vom aktiven Spieler kommt. Danach gibts Punkte je nachdem wie gut geraten wurde.
Ich hatte mich anfangs "geweigert" das Spiel zu spielen. Nachdem ich aber alle Spiele mindestens einmal mitspielen muss, bevor ich sage, dass es schrott ist, habe ich mich weichklopfen lassen (damals). Heute spiele ich Dixit sehr sehr gerne. Ein tolles Spiel, das die Phantasie anregt und ich habe auch festgestellt, dass ich gar nicht mal so schlecht darin bin die Anderen einzuschätzen (gut, selbst Begriffe ausdenken... aber im einschätzen der anderen...).
An einem Spiel bis 30 Punkte bekommt man aber auch den Kartenstapel des Grundspiels tatsächlich durchgespielt. Wenn man es öfter spielt, sind schon fasst Begriffe zu den einzelnen Karten fest eingebrannt... Da lohnt sich die ein oder andere Erweiterung tatsächlich mal :).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
PnP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good to play with creative people and with kids.  Obviously it's a party game, but it's even kind of less cerebral than other party games that I like.  It's really just about figuring out what other people will notice and what they won't.  I do enjoy this game a fair amount, especially because the artwork puts it over the top.  It's super interesting and fun to talk about and whimsically-styled.

The one downside is that, you're trying to be clever, but in this game it doesn't pay to be the most clever.  Actually, if you're too clever, no one will get what you were trying to hint at, and you will get no points that round, and everyone else will give points.  So you really have to dumb down your hints to make sure that some people get it.

But it's still a good game for practicing your people-intelligence.  Sure, that can be a word.

Also, this is my wife's favorite game, so that helps a lot.

RATING: 5

RATING: 5
Despite that I generally don't like party games, this one has great art, a good scoring mechanic, and if not gamed (e.g. my roommate wants only 1 person to choose the right card, so he gives an obscure Pokemon-related clue that he knows only I'll get) the strange art makes for some interesting interpretations. I would recommend getting an expansion though, as otherwise you will basically run through the deck every game. 

EDIT: It seems like it is really difficult to find a group where there isn't at least one person who specifically says something obscure that they know exactly one person knows just to get points. Since there doesn't seem any easy way to counteract this with the given mechanisms, I am dinging this game's rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My favorite card is the sad snowman. I actually made it my background for a while. I have a great picture of my dad imitating it after a pitcher of margaritas. That was a fun night.

In this game, everyone has abstract paintings in their hand that you want people to guess. Basically, one person gives a phrase that fits their card, everyone puts in a card that fits the phrase, and then you guess which card was the original phrase giver's card. If everyone or no one gets it, everyone but the phrase giver gets points. Otherwise, everyone that guessed it and the giver get points. You also get points for everyone that guessed yours. It's basically Balderdash for abstract pictures.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[microbadge=5322]

A bizarre game. It's odd how everyone is constantly on the look out for the party game that is still a gamer's game. I'm not sure Dixit is quite it yet. There is no real strategy; instead, you are supposed to be sold on the experience of developing and manipulating short stories with pictures. The game can be brilliant or it can fall flat. It depends on the group, and even with a good group, it can depend on the round. The game also goes very quickly, probably too quickly. A game like Dixit needs to be played like Poker to a certain extent, but lacking the length of Poker, the game has no chance to normalize.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There's nothing new mechanically about this game; basically it's just BALDERDASH with pictures. But playing it is an absolutely novel experience. The key is the way that the card art both encourages and seems to resist simpleminded paraphrase. I was worried that some less literary types amongst my gaming buddies might get left behind when it came to describing the pictures with the required subtlety, or guessing from amongst each row of pictures which one best fit a given description. But that didn't end up happening at all - all of our games were amazingly close, and everybody goofed up funnily a few times and had a few startling insights. Few games make you feel that their inventors have tapped into some hitherto ignored aspect of human nature - this one really did for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Le plus poétique des jeux. Une formidable réussite graphique et éditoriale. Un succès largement mérité. Même si les suites ont voulu surf sur le succès, je conseille la toute première version.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Some reviewers have suggested that the small number of cards gives thisgame a short life - this is false. As players become more familiar with the cards, it becomes harder to come up with clues that are neither too easy nor too hard. This makes for a game gets genuinely more challenging with time - which I find refreshing.

This game has gorgeous components and artwork, to the extent that I think the publisher could make a tidy profit selling posters of the artwork.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Игра-шедевр. Игра-выход за рамки стереотипов.
Впервые узнав о Диксит, я было подумал, что это будет интересная и незамысловатая семейная игра.
После первой партии я хотел выкинуть ее подальше и забыть.
Потом, силой случая, довелось сыграти в абсолютно незнакомой компании. Это перевернуло мое отношение на диаметрально противоположное.
Эта игра, как и многие, заставляет анализировать. Только не сложившуюся на столе игровую ситуацию, а себя и других людей. Смотришь на картинки и думаешь ЧТО мог загадать ЭТОТ человек? Смотришь на свои карты, а в голове роятся совершенно непредсказуемые мысли.
Если Вы хотите понять насколько хорошо знаете своих друзей или родных - сыграйте с ними в Диксит.

RATING: 7
A more family friendly alternative to Cards Against Humanity. A player gives a clue pertaining to a card he/she holds and other players add their own cards to the mix that may be similar to the clue. The goal is to determine which of the cards belongs to the clue giver. With gorgeous illustrations, this game will have you looking at things in ways you may not have before.

RATING: 9.5
A game that is simple, yet can be as deep as you want to make it. Perfect. You can get a lot out of each card, and while 84 cards in the base set is a lot, people will feel like the whole deck gets cycled through too much. So you will want to get an expansion quick. The only way I see people not liking this game is if they really don't care about art, or guessing games, but personally this is such a fun game that changes depending who you are playing with. I think every collection should have a copy. I haven't gotten bored with this game yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Everyone knows Dixit don't they? From a set of about 84 family friendly Dali/Magritte/de Chirico - like picture cards you each have a 6 card hand. Taking turns as the lead player, you associate a phrase with one of the cards in your hand. All other players pick a card that matches the theme from their hand. All cards played blindly in the middle, shuffled and then all non-lead players vote on which card they think the lead player played. Points are won by a couple of different rules on who voted for what, and if you can convince the other players that your card was played by the lead player.

It's a great family game and one of our favourites, but two caveats;

Firstly you have to play the game very different with players from different generations. Like Codenames, for me, the game loses some of its nuances when played with kids. It's still enjoyable but I enjoy the adult game, with more abstract/complex phrases/associations.

Secondly, I was very surprised at how quickly the cards in the base game seemed stale and repetitive. Even the young kids commented on this after a few games "awwww I don't want this one I've had this snake in the basket before", cue changing out the card as everyone now knows what they had. Kids hey! shake But fortunately expansions for Dixit seem to reproduce like tribbles so if you want to buy them you will never be short of options.

It is popular for a reason, great game.

UPDATE

My family loves this game and it is constantly requested. I have only played it with the family so far but would love to try it with just adults to see how different the game play is. I had the same experience with codenames recently and enjoyed the game a lot more when playing with only adults (as a gamer that is, I always enjoy playing games with the family and kids ... I am sure you know what I mean!)

We only have the base game and there have been comments that the same cards always seem to come around. Would love to get another deck of cards for Dixit, Is there one that you would recommend over the others?

RATING: 7.5
[b]Interesting game. Has a bit of a problem with clues that are tailored to one specific person only, in particular if the same two people do this repeatedly. This can take a lot of the fun out of it.
To prevent established patterns from appearing, one can restrict the clues to one specific topic or area of knowledge that all the players are familiar with. We once played a game in which all clues had to be Star Trek related.
Also, shared knowledge doesn't automatically mean the other person gets your hint, so there is potential for fun/frustrating misunderstandings.[/b]

[i]Houses "Dixit 2".[/i]

RATING: 7
Interesting story-telling card game.  A little like Apples-to-Apples.  Art is beautiful, too.  While creativity is required to play, each round has a definitive "correct" answer, unlike Apples-to-Apples, where the winner is solely at the whim of the active player.  The active player also has to play an interesting balancing act between too-obvious and too-far-out-there when coming up with a clue.

RATING: 6
A open-ended game, where you give hints for a picture you want others to find. However, others will lay down similar pictures to be misleading. The object is to only have "some" people, not all, find your picture. You face a penalty if everyone or no one finds it.

RATING: 7
Considering my general dislike of most social games, I'm surprised that I actually enjoyed this. I attribute this to the wonderful, Daliesque artwork that made me want to play certain cards even if they were inappropriate for the clue. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2nd best game of 2008 and one of my top10 favorites.
Awesome party game that anyone can enjoy. It's bit hard to 'get' as new player, but it's still fun to guess others cards even if your own explanations suck. Actually I'm not that good explainer myself, but I still love trying. The artwork is great, in Dixit and the first expansion at least, others in series are bit worse but still good. Dixit is great game to play with introverted people aswell. It allows you to be creative but never embarasses anyone. You don't have to try too hard to be funny, you can even be all serious and play to fun, but at some point fun will come!

2-Player Comment:
* Dixit can't be played with two. BGG Forums have some decent co-op variants for two, but otherwise it simply isn't a 2p suitable game. With three use this variant: in voting phase add random card (from draw deck) to choices.

Expansions:
+Dixit 2
+Dixit 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game is rarely boring.  You begin to get to know your opponents pretty well over time, and improve your score while doing so.  It's creative, the art is colourful and inspiring (inspiring what?  well, that's what you'll find out as you play)  I've played this at least 5 times with didn't groups, and several people have decided to go out and buy it.  It's not a hard game to reproduce using your own pictures and voting tokens, keeping track of scores on a piece of paper.  I've used the expansion in that exact way, and it didn't destroy the fun of game whatsoever.  I recommend Balderdash, and Apples to Apples if you're looking for similar game mechanics and fun.

RATING: 9
Amazing! the inductive nature of Dixit is pure genius, it prizes empathy, intuition, good abstraction skills and of course, your knowledge about persons and things. The paintings are weird and ambiguous but so well done, remarkable how a game with such simple rules can be also very complex. The game can get samey after many plays, however with expansions/more cards Dixit can be a 9 for me.

I play with all my Dixit cards mixed together, so I won't record any plays of expansions to be clear of how many actual times I've played the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
3-6 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was quite keen to play this game, sadly for me the down-time when it isn't your turn to be the Storyteller is really quite boring, as there's very little strategy that can be planned ahead there's not a lot to be done when you aren't picking a card from your hand or voting on which one you this is the Storyteller's. The game produces some moments of humour as people question why on earth somebody voted for a particular card but all too often I found myself just discarding a card out of my hand for no better reason than that I had something in mind for another card - maybe it was the descriptions we were using but 90% of the time I had nothing even remotely suitable to play as a reasonable alternative to the Storyteller's statement. 
When it is your turn to be Storyteller the game suddenly gets a lot more interesting as it is surprisingly enjoyable trying to decide how to pitch your statement so that (ideally) only one person gets it right, playing on common interests / experiences etc is very enjoyable and there's (bizarrely) a sense of jeopardy. I played with 6 people and was frankly close to dozing off once or twice. I did okay (came second both times) but just couldn't get into the game really.

EDIT: Re-played a couple of times with 4 people and the game is much better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

This game manages to blend balderdash and apples to apples by using pictures and sentences.  I was underwhelmed when I read the rules to be honest.

But the game is MUCH better than I thought.  I shouldn't really be surprised because Balderdash is one of my all time favourites.

This would be a fitting addition to the SdJ.  It is a game which would be an absolute hit in schools and family settings and has a broad, universal appeal.

So pretty!  Scoring system is arbitrary but irrelevant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a pretty enjoyable party game featuring wonderfully weird artwork. It's all about imagination and knowing each other. One player plays one of their cards face down and gives a theme, which can be absolutely anything you want, and the other players secretly play a card they think might fit that theme. After the cards are revealed players vote on which they think is the correct one and points are scored accordingly. It works well in a family setting, though with kids it depends on their ability to think abstract.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game, Love how this plays 'who done it' will have you laughing all night on why did that person play that card, what were they thinking?! I love bringing this game to groups. Cant wait to get some expansion cards! Very abstract art, can make several concepts out of each image.

RATING: 9
I love this game! One of my first games when I got back into the board gaming hobby after almost two decades (my last games before this were Gammarauders in the 80's and The Great Khan Game in the 90s).

It's remarkably simple and easy to teach, but really fun if you're in a friendly group, or in a group of your friends. The cards are wonderful and expansions just keep adding more.   The cards are also useful for other things (like playing Codenames or using for Fortune Telling or whatever). A must have in any collection IMO.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
*June 5, 2013* Risky buy, but paid off! I hosted a boardgame night and knew some of the players would only want to play Boggle, Scattergories, Taboo, and other snooze-worthy games. Risked it, even though I knew I'd be playing Clash of Cultures instead and the others would be playing this on their own.

My wife and 4 other friends played it... and she loved it! This is great news because it puts my games in a more positive context in her mind, as right now she feels extremely negatively about them (not where she minds my playing, just whenever it affects her). She's an artist so loves the art. She basically gave me a free pass to get Dixit Quest. The game looks like fun, I'd be glad to play it (just not overdo it, like The Resistance). 

Every play has Dixit Quest and latest Dixit Odyssey expansion mixed in

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With the right group of people, this game is an absolute riot!  The right group are people more interesting in telling cool stories, and interested in the same types of stories (for me that means crude immature adult humor of course).  But if you had a different sense of humor and played with like minded people, you'd bust up playing this game also.  Or a group of people who wanted to spin tales of fantasy or fairy tales to each other would enjoy this on a more cognitive, or traditionally creative level.

ADVICE: thought the scoring system is great (being balanced and concrete unlike judge scoring games), it's still better to play for the laughs than the score.

RATING: 8
Minden szavával egyetértek:

"A képek alapján elsőre dedósnak tűnhet a horrorfaló nagyfiúk számára a Dixit – de ebben az esetben sem szabad pusztán külcsín alapján ítélni. A Dixit szempillantás alatt lett az egyik legkedveltebb és legkeresettebb társas, nem ok nélkül. Egyszerű és nagyszerű! (...)

A Dixit átütő sikere miatt azóta több kiegészítő is megjelent, amik új lapokat tartalmaznak, ezeket szabadon lehet vegyíteni. Egy lapról pedig minden ember más és más dologra asszociálhat, így az újrajátszhatósága garantált. Nagyon szeretem, tipikusan ez is olyan játék, ami szikrát lehel a társaság szociális életébe. Társassal sohasem játszó emberek elé is vittem már: a kezdeti élénk tiltakozás két percig sem tartott, majd félóra elteltével már jöttek a dicsérő mondatok, hogy milyen jó ez a játék." (geekz.blog.hu)

Egyébként vannak egész jó két játékos variánsok is, érdemes a bgg adatlapján a file-ok között körülnézni (én töltöttem fel).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love that it can be enjoyed by my whole family and non-gaming friends but still has elements of strategy. (unlike other popular party games we play like Apples to Apples)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An unusual and original game which consists of players, on their turn,describing an aspect of an image on a card in their hand. The other players then put down a card that may, in some way, match the description. All the other players then vote for the card they think the description represents. If everyone, or no one, guesses your card you score no points. So, the trick is to employ an indeterminate description to score points. A good game to play with kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The artwork on the cards and box is gorgeous. Want to play.

Did play. Takes a little time to figure out the sweet spot for making your clues obscure, but not TOO obscure. You want someone to guess right, and you want people to play cards that fall in line with your clue. Very group dependent. Sometimes no one has any cards that fit your clue and things are obvious.

Fun game for the right group. Not my kind of game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good party game. The art lifts this above other games. Some slight concerns over replayability, but that's why there are expansions, which are easy to produce as long as artists keep drawing new cards (and it might be cool to see different-style expansions by other artists).

Suggest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We've enjoyed several plays of this game although it can be a little intimidating at first for new players. It takes quite a while to get good at giving clues that are just right, not too obscure, not too obvious. It's really fun to give long clues that work: my longest so far was seventeen words.* Many of the cards are very interesting, some are beautiful and poetic, and some are quite bizarre. Well worth buying the expansion deck, which easily fits in the base game box if you turn the insert upside down. [8 plays]

*In our most recent game, it became a point of honor to try to make your clue at least one word longer than the previous one. And so it went from five or six gradually on to something like twelve or thirteen words. Very satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Pros:

Beautiful artwork and fun social game where the active player gives a clue and all other players place a card they think will match that clue. Then, everyone votes on what card they think was the active players.

Cons:

Can lose replay value after repeated playthroughs because the game is dependent on the artwork on the cards and that can get stale. I guess that's what expansions are for?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Such a great game that is open to just about any person...gamer or non-gamer.

Each round a player must say a keyword that relates to one of their cards. Each player then selects a card from their hand that best matches or has a link to the keyword. The active player adds their card to the mix and randomly shuffles and sets them out.

Each player then tries to guess which was the original card. Players then earn points based on if their guess was correct and if any other players selected the card they put out as an option. 

The centerpiece is the gorgeous artwork of the oversized cards that are very evocative. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Almost a perfect family game for five or six players. Easy to teach and challenging for both kids and adults. Only bad things are that you will begin to remember the cards when you play it a lot. But there are expansions to get.

RATING: 7

Mysterium has kind of replaced Dixit for me (though lately Deception has maybe replaced Mysterium...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a game for creatives. If you want to sit back, roll the die and let the game just happen as it may - Dixit isn't for you. The artwork in the box is simply stunning. I'd be tempted to buy an extra copy just to take them all out and frame them around my house; and unusually, the game revolves all around the art. The mechanic is similar to Balderdash or Mysterium; the 'Storyteller' selects an image from their hand and names it, with other players attempting to submit a different picture that matches the title. There's something very zen and calming about Dixit. It really is interesting to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This fun party game resembles a combination of Apples to Apples and Balderdash. Players are dealt cards with cartoonish pictures. The current player says a sentence, or hums a tune to convey the meaning of a picture, then a card is placed face down out of their hand. Everyone else then plays a face down card. Cards are revealed and players have to choose the the current player's card to score points. You also score points if people choose your card.

It's a different game, fun to play at a party,and was the French game of the year in  2009. It would be interesting to see how replayable it is, though I heard there are expansions already. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good, honest fun.

RATING: 8.6

Also, it keeps topping the charts as one of the best party games ever. If I really like this, I'll get all the expansions too.
----------
For a "small numbers party game" i.e. a party style game but you still sit around a table, for something you can play with non gamers and casual gamers, for something that is a great alternative to older more boring party games like pictionary charades, etc. This one IS KING!

Dixit is just one of the greatest games in that it's universally fun and interesting. It's immediately accessible, super fun, rewarding even when you're not winning and imaginative. I prefer this game over apples to apples or cards against humanity and even though I probably like Balderdash just as much for slightly different reasons despite having the same niche, this one is even more accessible and fast paced. Great game!

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Relating to Apples to Apples (which I loathe) I love this game for two main reasons:

1. It uses your imagination.
2. There is not just one judge deciding the random lucky winner. It uses a voting system.

Those two simple combinations make the game enjoyable to me.  

Apple to Apples gets very old, even when playing with a different group.  Since Dixit uses your imagination, every time you play with a different group, there are lots of laughs because of all the crazy ideas people have as to what the cards remind people of.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My party-game of choice. Best played with people who like creative things, those with artistic and writing aspirtaions can excel in the game, yet it is not a must. The art of the cards by Marie Cardouat, who obviously is a well-seasoned illustrator of children's books, is fantastic - the attention to detail and fantasy applied to the images is stunning.  Some people are vary of the game because you can apply the 'strategy' of only giving very personal hints that can be understood by your spouse or any other 'insider' - yet this is a *choice* of the players. If you refrain from this strategy you will get so much more out of this game and it really develops both fantasy and creativity. I see no reason other than adding some components why the game cannot be played with up to 8 or 9 people. As a party game, Dixit obviously has a strong element of randomness as you cannot know if your very well thought out clue or metaphor just has no equivalent in your opponents' cards, while at other times they do. The only real down-side I can see to the game is that some people have a problem with coming up with new descriptions/sentences for the cards once you've played them all a couple of times - but there's always Dixit 2 that can remedy this...

RATING: 1
The optimal play as the judge is for only one person to guess your card. That way you get 3 points and only one other person gets 3 points. So the optimal play is to just grunt and not give any clue at all. Then random chance ensures a high likelihood that at least one player will choose your card. Seems broken to me.

RATING: 5.3
A wonderful, creative game that suffers from two large flaws. First, it wears out its welcome quickly, with cards growing stale after only a few appearances and individual games sometimes dragging on too long. Secondly, it's a party game that relies upon invention and interpretation, which aren't universal skillsets, potentially leaving some players or groups apathetic or even uncomfortable with the game. Ultimately, I find that it's a great game (activity?) in concept that becomes less enchanting in actual play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a party game running along the same notions as Balderdash or Fibbage, but in which vague descriptions of surreal images are used to form the questions, instead of words or trivia. Dixit is light, quick, endlessly diverse and incredibly easy to learn – but the fact that players functionally generate their own questions does leave it tragically open to "exploitative" play. The base game also desperately requires Dixit Odyssey in order to expand the player limit and accommodate large groups. 

Approved.

RATING: 2.5
I always want to like Dixit more than I actually do.

My desire is to play with a group of storytellers, who are look at the cards available and weave simple tales that are clever and concise, and can be interpreted in different ways but clearly point to the chosen card when you understand their intent.

My reality is that it's a breeding ground for the least imaginative or expressive in-jokes and statements specifically designed to exclude one particular person...

Clues like: "that thing we were talking about in the car on the way over," make me want to cry. It's like playing Balderdash with people who can't form a grammatically correct sentence.

Expansions owned:
* Odyssey (2011)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game exercises a very different part of the brain than most boardgames, combining a person's verbal ability to selectively describe to their audience, along with the deductive ability to discern the truth when not playing the storyteller. It excels for people who do not want to over analyze problems during a game.

Having an experienced player model several different types of storytelling methods can help open up the game to more creative stories. I also find that as an ice breaker, it is useful to ask why each person guessed a particular card. Although it slows the game down, it helps a new group understand each other for better play each round.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Exactly the type of party game I actively avoid: You have to make up stories or hints about your cards. These kinds of performances belong in a high school drama club, not in a board game.

The game also suffers from the usual problem of hint-based party games: The main strategy here is to  know at least some of the other players so well (either in real life or from earlier experience with the game) that you can just keep racking up points using insider hints, and leaving the others completely without any possibilities to score.

And even if we don't consider that aspect at all, the scoring still does not work. The active player gets -2 points if everybody or nobody guesses the card, and +3 points otherwise. Even though other players can score a little during other players' turns by cleverly choosing their cards, that just doesn't balance the scoring enough. You should definitely get rewarded more if you come up with creative hints and only a few players get it right. But actually, that would just encourage using the insider hint approach, so looks like we have a kind of a catch-22 situation here.

There are way too few cards: You'll have seen all of them pretty much during the first game, so making up fresh hints gets even more difficult very quickly.

The two reasons why I don't rate this any lower are:
First, the illustrations are absolutely fantastic. They should print posters and sell those instead.
Second, there's actually a game in here, even though it's not really a board game. In Finland, it's a television game show called [i]Kymppitonni[/i].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This can be really fun if and when played with the right people+right mood.
Excellent exercise of imagination.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dixit isn't always a 10 but it can be. Played with casual acquaintances or at a gaming day it's a great filler but nothing amazing. 

Amazing is playing it with your friends and busting out the real clues, like -
"How X will feel the moment he realises he's gay."
"How I felt the day I saw the baby ultrasound picture on my ex's facebook."
"What my in-laws really think of me."

The cards are surpisingly versatile for plumbing the depths of your friends' depravity and your own personal tragedies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Whimsical party game where lateral thinking is encouraged.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The idea behind Dixit is simple and wonderfully original: a "declaring" player says a phrase associated to one card in their hand, the other players choose a card from their respective hands that matches the phrase as closely as possible, all cards are mixed together and then they've got to guess which card was the original one - if all players or none guess the card all players but the "declarer" score 2 points, otherwise all players with right guesses and the declarer score 3 points and owners of misleading cards score 1.

If this concept is already enough to guarantee an excellent, balanced game, the artwork makes it one of the most memorable games of late: all cards include pictures of a childlike, dreamy quality, avoiding easy associations and giving every session a unique, playful touch. It's barely possible to think of a better way to meld creativity, poetry and a good amount of chuckles around a table.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gioco geniale, la maggior parte degli amici a cui l'ho fatto provare mi ha poi chiesto di comprarglielo. Ha il vantaggio di essere semplice e corto: si spiega in 1 minuto e le partite durano circa 30'. Ideale per serate all'insegna del divertimento, Dixit è un family game adatto anche ai più piccoli. A farla da padrone non è la strategia (che solitamente prediligo) ma la fantasia, l'intuizione e, a volte, anche un po' di cultura generale (dipende con chi lo si gioca). Un consiglio: massima attenzione ai dettagli... Il gioco, che trovo dovrebbe manderà in cantina i vari Taboo e Pictionary, potrebbe avere una distribuzione migliore perché adatto realmente a tutti e capace di avvicinare come nessun altro i babbani ai giochi in scatola. Lo consiglio anche se dopo i tanti premi il prezzo è salito troppo. Ha il limite di essere per massimo 6 giocatori (è uscita l'espansione Odyssey che permette partite anche in 12), ma può essere scaricata l'espansione fino a 8. I disegni sulle carte sono bellissimi e fantasiosi. Una volta entrati nel tunnel non potrete fare a meno delle numerose espansioni che regalano maggiore longevità.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It works well enough, crossing Thingamajig with Apples to Apples. Instead of a word, you pitch in a secret picture with a cryptic clue. Everyone else pitches in a secret picture trying to match that clue. The pictures get shuffled and revealed, then each player other than the clue giver secretly chooses which one they think was the clue giver's picture. To maximise points as the clue giver, you only want one person to guess, and definitely not all and not no one. As the non clue givers, you maximise points by picking the right one and having everyone else pick yours. The pictures are suitably wild and esoteric, allowing for all sorts of weird clues. You get through the whole deck in each game, so the trick is either to play with the same group each time and watch the emergence of more clever clues for the same old pictures, or continually play with new groups to keep it fresh. Or buy expansions. It's one of the downsides. It's simple, it's enjoyable enough, it's not too long for what it is. It's got the same card luck as Apples to Apples - either you'll have something that's close to the clue given or not. So you can't take it too seriously. It's not something I'll seek, but I'd say yes if anyone wanted to play. As long as it's occasional, not all the time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Group dependent.  After a few games you see the same cards, and clues may repeat themselves depending on who you are playing with.  This may require you to buy expansions....which is an investment.  So how invested is your gaming group?  Also, you need to play with people who are very creative and who enjoy the activity.

RATING: 8.5
I hate party games that  involve players accusing other players of being traitors, within the first three seconds, and having endless discussions over their beliefs. I also hate charades.

This game came as a breath of fresh air, to save me from committing suicide or murder. Clever mechanics and nice surreal  components. 

I am really self conscious so I also appreciate that I don’t have constant pressure to come up with clues. I only give a clue once in every 5 or 6 rounds and I enjoy the rest of the game in comfort. Even when I have to give a clue, I can choose from 6 cards.

Different experience with different game groups. Great Game. Thank God!

(Wife's Point of View: She loves it. Too bad you can't play Dixit with 2-p)

I look forward to playing the game with 5 or 6 and raising it to a 8+ in rating.

TableTop S1E12
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The board, a platform built around the perimeter of the box, and the wooden rabbit player tokens are clever.  I didn't like the game very much.  Everyone gets a hand of cards that have different pictures on them.  The "Storyteller" chooses one of her cards and tells everyone a word, phrase, or paragraph that is supposed to hint at the picture on her card without actually describing it.  Then everyone else chooses a card to match the Storyteller's description and all the cards go into a pile and are mixed together.  The Storyteller arranges the cards randomly, face up, on the table.  Players use numbered chips to vote for the card each thinks best matches the Storyteller's description and everyone tosses their chips out at once.  Points are awarded for choosing the correct card as well as fooling other people into voting for your card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Simply put, Apples to Apples with pictures instead of words. This provides more freedom for all players, the one giving the clue has their whole range of experience available, and the other players are forced to find a card in their hands that fits rather than going to blatant humor. The scoring forces the clue giver to be clever, but not too clever.

RATING: 6
Very unique game. It's a party game for the sophisticated urban elite.

Players take turns as the storyteller. 

The storyteller plays a hidden card and says a sentence. All the other players must then play a card that "matches" the sentence. All the cards are revealed and everybody will try to guess which card was played by the storyteller. The trick is that points are awarded only if some players guess it right and some guess it wrong, making the storyteller's job much harder. 

None of this would work, of course, without the stunning art in the cards, by Marie Cardouat.It's almost worth it to buy the game for the art alone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros
Amazing art
Easy to teach, easy to play

Cons
Fun depends of the group
Replayability for same group with same cards is bad
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
I like the tricky nature of describing a card in enough detail to convince some people but not all. I also like that everybody votes secretly, so it isn't like Apples to Apples with the one person judging. Some of the descriptions are so funny, and the cards people choose can be really entertaining. I think it would be fun to get the expansion, since we went through the cards pretty quickly and more variety would be nice. This game isn't a wild laughing game like Time's Up or Balderdash--it's more quiet and mellow. It is better with 5-6 players, not as good with 4. I happen to be terrible at it, but I still enjoy it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Please don't make me play this game again!  The gameplay is okay -- there are 100 or so cards with illustrations that look like they were drawn by Salvador Dali during his worst nightmares -- and the "active" player gives some label to a card and the other players try to guess which card he/she has labelled.  Well, yes, that is very lame, but it's okay, easy to learn, and moves along quickly.  But, I may not sleep for a week thinking about how extremely annoying and disturbing the artwork is on these cards.  I mean, one card has an alien with a hose coming out of a nostril, and you're supposed to describe it such that some opponents can figure out which card it is, but others can not.  If they all figure out your card based on your definition -- or if none do -- then you score no points.  I learned this at a game club, Dixit was being played at 4 separate tables -- the moment the games completed at each table it was quickly put away and the players rushed to the game shelf to find something different -- and much better -- to play.  Now, time to go to bed -- but I'm still thinking of that alien with a hose up his nose, or the mother trying to pull her daughter out of the throat of a monster trying to swallow her.  Yick!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Whoa! This game tests the creative part of brain of everyone. I played the game with 3 players and it worked fine, but I can see this game shine with 5 to 6 players.

I found out the hard way, I am not a creative person! Maybe I am biased but the 2 girls I've played with whooped my behind. Are girls better at this game?

----- Update ----
After around 20 plays this game drops from a 8 to a 7. Replay-ability is definitely an issue at this play count. I see it will hit the table from time to time but I won't actively suggest it anymore. Maybe when the right mood and with the right group this will come out. Oh and girls are not better at this game after the guys' brains got trained to play this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've played Dixit enough now to give it an honest rating - as well as add a few comments.

Dixit is a very easy game to learn how to play but can be very difficult to master.  In order to succeed, you have to try and get a glimpse into the mind of the storyteller in order to decipher his/her card.  The art is fantastic, and is compelling to everyone I've ever introduced the game to.  

Like any game, it's not a game for everyone.  There is no hard-core strategy, it takes a very creative mind to enjoy this, and it truly is about the playing as opposed to the winning.

I've introduced this game to many people and I find it's been a real hit with non-gamers.  I wouldn't classify it as a gateway game, because there is no game like it and there is no 'next step'.  It's just a fantastic 'party' game.  I'll always enjoy playing Dixit, and I always recommend that if you're going to buy this, you also buy Dixit 2, at least. (If you like it, Dixit: Odyssey will likely follow!)

---
[b]Game Duration:[/b] (Very Short) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Very Long)

RATING: N/A
8+, 3-6 (Best 5-6) 30mins 
Not a fan of the fantasy art, thinking of using Musee/Big Picture Apples to Apples instead. But not only the art, but I'm not a fan of using exclusivity to score points, I think Dohdles gets around this type of tightrope scoring better.

Might be a good mind searching exercise to throw out a clue in family and friend gatherings that hopefully scores highly via vagueness. Might also stimulate conversation from why certain clues given or how they find meaning. Seems to get stale fast with seeing the same cards more variety means either buying more cards or playing with different people to hear different interpretations of the same card.

From TableTop video: Apples to Apples style card play in which the turn player adds a card to the mix after stating a clue as to the card played, so a test of creativity and tuning into what others may think or know, so may advantage the competitive player who know some inside information . One hurdle to the game is the scoring method which rewards being vague but not too much (as in Teubers Barbarossa). However this hurdle maybe be overlooked by the engaging puzzle as to which card best fits the statement and the reason behind the clue.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
This game combines intelligent and innovative gameplay with beautiful aesthetics. The concept is simple: give clues about your cards, without being too specific or too vague. The reason being - you only score points if some but not all of the other players guess your card correctly. The abstract artwork allows a great deal of creativity in crafting your clues (whilst giving ample room for other players to sneak in their cards). I love this game because it combines creative thinking with a strong level of social interaction. It usually gets people talking (even if it's simply to express utter confusion over the link between the clue and the card!) and it can get people in touch with considering other points of views - What would appeal to specific players? What does this clue say about the person giving it?

A unique addition to any gamer's collection!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Szeretem az ilyen asszociációs játékokat, főleg ha ilyen jó kártyákkal játszik az ember.

RATING: 7.5
Great game for people that do not like playing games. Very unusual game that works well during social events. Has great artwork and simple rules. Game-play is light allowing people to talk.
Base game has quite limited number of cards. Almost every game you will go through whole deck, which means you will be seeing the same cards repeatedly. Game needs other expansions to shine.
Jul 2013: 7.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dixit is a strange beast. It's a fun game, rewards creativity, and the art is fantastic. However, you will see most of the cards after just one play and it's a little too easy to take advantage of "inside" information between you and one or two of the other players (to each of your benefit, and the disadvantage of the rest of the group). Still, I think it's a great experience game and at 30 minutes, one I'd usually be willing to play. I wish there were more cards (like, 1000 instead of 80) but also realize this is unrealistic. You really need to change the cards up though to create a replayable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A unique and beautiful party game. It is fairly similar to the Apples to Apples type games, but has a very different feel to it.
