RATING: 5
So... I didn't... hate this like I thought I would. Dixit is a game where you choose an abstract picture say a sentence or less, and then you play Apples to Apples, except not as a shitty game with no creativity or interesting bits. The art is quite nice, and I like the artsy fartsy process of giving vague titles to cards or vice versa. But the game end where you're trying to score points feels sorta hollow, and there's a little too little emergent play, creatively, as the cards do much of the work. I almost want to get copy of the cards to just look at when I want to relax. But I don't really want to play a game with these cards.

RATING: 7
"A picture is worth a thousand words".
This game is truly unique, at least absolutely different from the rest of the games I know.
It has created a whole new category, that may not be large, relating gaming with emotions, psychology, literature...
We like it because it's very simple and a lot of fun, but also cause sometimes it unveils a little bit of what's inside of other players' minds.
It can be played with very different attitudes.
And kids love it. The bunnymeeples are a plus for them.

RATING: 9
Before playing this, I was so skeptical that this could work. It seemed like it would be weird or stupid or confusing or awkward or shallow or all of those at once.

It's not. It's so difficult to explain why this one works, but it does. This is the game you show to people to prove to them that board gaming is more than just a bunch of games for adolescents or fantasy geeks. It's even replayable, because you have to make up new stories each time you see the cards. It is like nothing else, in a good way. Everyone should try this game.

#3 on personal list "Top 10 hidden gems in tabletop gaming"

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Party games are tough. I don't like having to be funny on command, I don't like having to embarrass myself through acting, singing, dancing, waving my arms, or some other thing that I don't do when I have the choice. Forced camaraderie? I don't know. I'll risk the reputation of being a curmudgeon. 

Dixit is different. It's a creative activity, "be clever but not too clever," the art is gorgeous, and there's no hint of Performance Anxiety that most fellow Introverts would recognize from their personal histories of being forced to play Cranium or Charades, sitting there in a room with everyone staring at you as you try to remember how to hum the theme song to Hawaii Five-O and you feel your face getting more and more flushed. 

No, Dixit is different. It's very visual, it encourages conversation, the debrief between rounds is usually reminiscing and sharing passions, laughing over clues, who got what quotation wrong, was that from a Kids in the Hall skit? It's great. The whole thing is great. All while staring at a picture of a girl trapped in a birdcage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With the right crowd it can be an awesome game. Not for everyone though.

Even though it's for 3-6 players there's an interesting coop variant for 2 which i like to play with my wife. That said, it tends to start feeling the same after too many plays.

RATING: 6.75
Your Dixit experience really depends on who you are playing it. Playing it with hardcore gamers will result in consecutive moaning about how this is not a game. Playing it with geeks will result in myriads of LOTR and Dr. Who references being thrown around the table. If you play it with a healthy mix of open minded people it is great fun. Lots of laughs and great insights into peoples' personalities. The scoring system is incredibly confusing though and nobody, inlcluding the owner did not get it. Lovely game.

RATING: 3
Party game.  Lame.  If you like party games, then go ahead and torture yourself.  The artwork if I have to call it that is good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Perfect party game for non-gamers who do not like making a fool of themselves. Unfortunately, I prefer party games in which *you do* make a fool of yourself since I think the point of party games is to laugh yourself silly.

This isn't one of those games.

I thought this would have the same feel of Apples to Apples since you are making associations between two disparate things, in this case, a surreal picture and a phrase. However, the point of this game is to create a phrase accurate enough to describe a picture, but vague enough that only some (but not all) players could match that phrase with the picture. Consequently, there isn't much room for creative, witty, or ironic phrases.

For party games that involve creating a phrase given a question or phrase, then players guessing who wrote what, I'd rather play Say Anything or Things ... Humor in a Box. But that said, I'd rather play Dixit with my parents or people I don't know that well, since I don't want to make a fool of myself in front of either,
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a party game that is different from what you would typically think of when party game is mentioned. While all players submitting cards is again how the field is populated, everything else is a nice take on the genre. The active player deciding what the "story" is allows for more open ended discussion. The art is gorgeous and well done. Expansions also allow for more cards and different styles of art to enter the game which keeps its replayability high. But while a party game, it can still get old if played too long in one sitting and it is a little tougher to get to the table as it isn't for all groups while other party games are a bit more approachable. Plays up to six if you want to keep score and can go higher if you disregard keeping score and have expansions to keep the draw pile full.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dixit is certainly a party game.  If you don't like party games, you won't like Dixit.  Occasionally, I love a good party game, one that requires abstract thinking and creativity.  Dixit is a game that lets each player's creativity shine by asking the players to see many aspects the beautifully illustrated images.  Dixit requires serious out of the box thinking, and it can take time to get used to the idea of the game.  The rules are simple to learn, but it's hard to wrap your mind around the best way to play.  

I think the depth of the images leads to a lot of replayability.  Each time I take out the cards to look at them, I find more little details that I hadn't noticed before.  The number one reason to play Dixit is for the art, for the little details that make each card its own work of art; it's good that the game play is about the art or the cards would completely upstage the gameplay.  

I love the first moments of a game with people who have never played because when everyone looks at their first hand of cards, I can see how enchanted everyone is by the fabulous artwork.  That's exactly how I felt when I first picked up Dixit in the store to read the back of the box.  I had no idea what the game was about, but I knew I was going to go home and find out because if the game was even half as good as the artwork, I knew it would be a lot of fun to play.  Luckily, it is as fun to play as it is beautiful.

Good game, suffers from a replayability standpoint.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Description: Storytelling, association, party card game, with beautiful pictures, voting and light humor.
Weight: Pretty light.
Players: 3 to 12 with expansion. Best with 5 or 6.

Impression: Light, beautiful card game that inspires imagination and wit. It consists of huge cards with fantastic and beautiful imagery, full of tiny details and dreamlike motives. The goal is that, on your turn, describe your own card however you like without showing it. Then the other players select a card in secret from their hand that best resembles your card. You then shuffle all the cards and display them for all other players to guess your card by secret voting. The trick is if all players correctly guess your card you get zero points. If no one guesses your card you get zero points. Simple and brilliant. And then it goes in circles. It works very well when you know how other players think.

Likes: Beautiful drawings. Imaginative. Quick and fun.

Dislikes: Not good and very random with more than 6 players. Needs expansions to stay fresh. Expansions have different artists and styles, not always constructive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Slightly better than Apples to Apples, but still pretty meh.

:star::star::star::star::halfstar: [b]Artwork[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Mechanics (general gameplay "fun")[/b]
:star::star::star::star::nostar: [b]Rules (easy to learn/teach)[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Replay Value[/b]
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: [b]Player Uptime[/b]
:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Meaningful Decisions (luck factor)[/b]
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: [b]Total[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A nice, friendly and calming game that exercises the same 'imagination' brain muscles as games like Mysterum and Spyfall.

The (potentially significant) problem with the gameplay is that pairs of players who have very niche common interests can explot that to massive advantage - undermining the whole game. This is because the best result each round is to give a very cryptic clue that only one other person understands. So if you and your friend are massive Led Zepellin fans you'll probably want to keep making obscure Led Zepellin references to get high scores, effectively aliening the other players from having any chance to score in your turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.75
Have played this a few times.  I don't find it as funny as Apples To Apples, but the people that hate A2A because of the arbitrary judging like this.

It's a fine game to bust out in mixed company.  After one round, everyone gets how things works and plays well.  But after a few plays, it can be hard to not use the same clue or even telegraph to a specific person, which card is yours.  More cards would help with that problem, but given the cost of the expansions, that's unlikely to happen.

Decent party-type game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Look at a card, tell a story in one sentence (or make a literary allusion). Each other player then puts in a card and everyone else at the table has to guess which of the cards you were describing. To score some must guess and others must miss, so the game is about being cryptic enough to confuse some players but clear enough to get at least one on your card.
The mechanism is clever and it has been used in trivia games and the like but this remains more of a party game than a real challenge. Given the right group of players it could be huge fun, but with the wrong players I think it fail rather badly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
This totally seems like it would be a party game, and exactly the kind of game I'd hate, but it is not.  It is saved by a few very important factors:

1. The scoring system
2. There is no "judging" player selections; there is a distinct right and wrong answer.

These change this from a stupid exercise in forced socialization into an actual Game that is definitely worth playing.

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Whole family enjoys it from the 6yo to my wife and I so it has great reach that way. The gameplay is fun - like apples to apples a bit, but I think dixit is a better incarnation of the basic idea. Words are harder to match meanings than a vague description of quirky pictures are. The only complaint I have so far after about a half-dozen plays is that with so few cards, I think people have seen all of them several times and that's a) starting to stifle the "stories" (i.e. it's hard to come up with something no one's heard before) and b) it's easier to guess which card they may be looking at since you've got a sort of catalog of available cards in your head. Still, this one hit an extraordinarily rare niche where EVERYBODY not only likes it but can play it fairly competitively.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice simple game. I think it must be played with at least 5 people.

The real interesting part is coming up with the sentence that will not be to easy or too hard.  The rest is pretty standard. Fun to be had, but maybe a little light for my taste.

After another few plays with 5 and 6 players I will stand by my statement that it's still a little too light for me. Works great for families and new games though.

it's a nice idea and it's nice to be creative but there's not much 'game' here AND it's just not a lot of fun.

having said that the 2 NGs we played with both liked it and wanted to play again which is cool but i don't see yet why this is getting more love than other similar party games...

NOTE - i feel the game is poorly presented - the box is nice but for a game about 'feel' and 'experience' the rules do nothing to draw u into a fantastical surrealy dream landscape of the mind - also the cutesy scoretrack and bunnies is unforgiveable for a non-kids game. lastly i find it inconceivably that for a game of this type the only example for a story-teller in the English rules is a reference to a French film!! y not have some more general examples of things u can say or at least change the reference to suit the language

RATING: 9.4
simply...beautiful

Our minor houserule for all versions of Dixit: Player who gives 'hint' (plays card) also votes during vote phase for 'best other' card (i.e. card this player thinks suits best to his hint). This way that player doesn't feel 'out of play' during voting phase.

RATING: 7
A creative language game that doesn't depend on arbitrary decisions of what's a legal word/sentence/etc. Good! You can actually play it competitively. Cool art.

http://www.transparent.com/esperanto/first_time_abroad_and_at_ijk/ has a photo of people playing Dixit at an Esperanto event in summer of 2011. I have often seen Dixit played at Esperanto events, which is fun, since we share a common language but totally different national cultural backgrounds, so references to old songs and TV shows and such don't play a role as they often seem to when everyone plays in the same national language.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
31-08-2014. Rated after 3 plays of various Dixit versions. I am not sure where I stand on this game. IF it's your turn, you play a card and hint/make a story/sing a song that you think symbolizes something on the card you've played. Other players than play a card that they think is similar. Players than vote on which card they think was from the original player. If no one guesses correctly, all other players gain two points. If at least one player guesses correctly both original player and correct guesser gain 3 points. So basically you want to be obscure, but not too obvious. 

I am not sure what I think about this game. I think it's ok, but it'll never become a game that I really, really, really enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A steady favorite at my house these days. The acting player says a one or two word clue and then each player supplies a card with an image that resembles what the acting player said. There is a twist. If everyone or no one guesses which card belongs to the acting player, the acting player loses points. You have to be able to get only some of the players to guess which card is yours. How you manage this is the secret to the game. This game is light hearted and a lot of fun. You need probably at least two expansions to make this game pop since there are simply not enough cards in the base set.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
One of the most unique board games I've encountered recently. It's a bit like Apples to Apples, but with artwork. I have only two possible negative comments: 1) after about 8-10 games, you start to get used to the cards, and 2) not enough playing chips. It allows for up to 6 players, but this would be a wonderful party game for even more!

Update: We now own Dixit Odyssey, and in one box we store all our cards from Dixits 1, 2, and 3. Also, there is the possibility for up to 12 players (even more for us, since we kept our pieces and voting cards from Dixit 1). I've increased my rating of this game accordingly.

RATING: 9.5
This will be one of my favourite games forever. A really pretty game that can change vastly depending on who you're playing it with. One of those rare games where winning is nice but doesn't matter terribly much to the enjoyment of it.

It mashes up really well with other games. (We play a 'Cards Against Dixit' variant, where instead of making up their own clue, each player gets ten random answer cards from 'Cards Against Humanity' and must select their clue from one of these cards.)

Awesome as an opener, a closer, and any time in between.

RATING: 8
This is my cup of tea. All in the box are pictures. The acting player has to describe one of your pictures, neither too obvious nor too obscure. Then everyone else try to play a picture to match that description and also guess the one that is played by the acting player. This game is about imagination, driven by players but not by the cards. With imaginative players around, this game can have infinite possibilities. On the contrary, if your friends are all very dull.... OK I know I am gonna badmouth the education in this country. RATING: 8
A great variation on the classic Balderdash where instead of given word people figure out a sentence (often a single world) which best describes a picture (beautiful art in this game) and the others pick a card from their hand which best fits the description. Scoring goes very much like in Balderdash. We had great fun playing with my wife, another couple and my five year old daughter. We all could enjoy the game.

RATING: 7.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I just played Dixit this weekend, and, yeah, see an Apples to Apples mechanic: As one of the other players, you're given a topic you must attempt to match, and sometimes the random assortment of cards you have match, and sometimes they don't.

As said, the hint-giving mechanic isn't unique, either. Just after Dixit, we played Linq (?), in which you give a hint that's understandable to your partner, but not the other players.

Dixit also isn't immune to the "couple's advantage", in which two players who have "insider's knowledge" can share information unavailable to other players. As a competitive player, myself, a hint I gave was "No, I'm a villager". No points as to what shape a certain shadow in the background was!

That being said, Dixit's surreal images certainly stand out. It's definitely uncommon for a party game to have pictures, and I can't think of any with such striking ones. And you can use the cards as story elements to make your own fairy tale game!

I'll probably pick this one up in trade, or at a deep discount. That's more than I can say for nearly all party games out there!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
My family (have you noticed a theme for this category?) has loved this one ever since it was published, even though only a few of us can play it with any skill. But winning doesn't matter here, the answers are so delightful and unexpected that asking 'why did you give that clue' is often the most entertaining part of the game. My favorite kind of clue is simply to name myself or another person at the table, and get the wonderful, startling, and awkwardly revealing answers that result.

Love that the game is 'tricking' people into paying money for art, that's delightful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Visual Appeal: (5)
The original art for this game is amazing. It will nearly always get positive remarks from new players. The game looks compact and attractive on the table.

Component Quality: (5)
The cards are over-sized and easy to see. They seem durable enough to remain un-sleeved and still last a long time. Bunny Meeples make a nice score keeper, although the scoring track is a little hard to follow.  

Theme: (4)
The game is what you make of it. It has as much theme as Pictionary until you start telling stories. I routinely play with writers, musicians, and other artistic persons who really bring the pictures alive and make some challenging choices for the listeners.

Learning: (5)
This game takes under 10 minutes to teach, and I've taught to 8 year-olds and 60 year-olds. I recommend letting the players look through all the pictures before playing. It benefits your stories if you know what other players might be holding. The rulebook for my edition came in many languages, but I think each only required one page for the rules.

Gameplay: (4)
I think there is some great interaction in this game. Some of the best moments are thinking of that story that only one other person at the table will relate to. Instead of feeling left out of the joke, other players are encouraged (and rewarded) by the game to attempt to draw others to choose their card instead.

Overall Fun: (5)
I have played this game all over the place. It is a short, simple game that is friendly to everyone willing to let their creative juices flow. I've been impressed by some of the people I've met and the things they came up with. Playing with new people actually makes the game more entertaining rather than a drag to re-teach and re-work a group dynamic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dixit took me completely by surprise. I had never even heard of it when I sat down at a table in the Cannes fair. And the five of us (who usually like "gamers" games) were totally convinced by the experience.

It's a game that can be enjoyed by everybody : the rules are extremely simple and the poetry will appeal to your average non-gamer. Still the agonizing choice of the right expression (when it's your turn) or of the right picture (when you have to vote) will remind gamers of much heavier games.

A wonderful piece of art, mainly thanks to the beautiful artwork by Marie Cardouat.

RATING: 4
Never played Apples to Apples or Say Anything before so I don't know how this one stands up to them. But it's fun! The ambiguous artwork gives the game character and makes it tick, and is best combined with thoughtful, ambiguous sentences. The game suffers a little in that it's good to play with experienced players to understand their tendencies, but the more you play, the more predictable the cards are. Bring on expansions!

The game can be really biased in favor of the player who happens to have cards that fit the sentence well, but it's a party game; who cares.

I don't like this as much as other people since so much of the game comes down to a blind guess between A and B. The "I picked this because of that time I blah blah, lolz!" afterward isn't always worth it.

RATING: 7.5
Cardgame of guessing the described card supported with very nice illustrations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
At its heart, Dixit requires people to think out of the box, but not too much. Toss in some highly surreal illustrations and some personal creativity, and this game can spring a lot of surprises when people explain the reason why they described their card so.

The only major caveat is that the game can be killed if the group insists on only using inside jokes and pop culture references when playing with people who aren't familiar with them. The nature of the game rewards inside references, so some self-regulation is needed on behalf of the group depending on who is playing. That aside, this is one party game deserving of its popularity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like Dixit. It's a beautiful game with a fun social mechanism that always has your group laughing and chatting. In the end, it's a very light game with an easy to learn system and gorgeous cards.  I'm not as picky about abstract art as some other people might be, so I just think it's all beautiful and awesome.

RATING: 8
[3 plays] The artwork is just fantastic, the quality of all components is very high, and the length of the game seems just right for a party game. I look forward to trying this with kids to see how they handle the imagination of the storytelling part.

We played with all adults, so we were a bit cautious , using mostly single word descriptions at first rather than "storytelling", but we did get a bit bolder with time. I enjoyed how this game played, the psychology of trying to get into the thoughts of the other players.

Most recent play 12-23-09 with Barb, Ruth, and the Davis clan.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
I played this game several times with a group of friends and just love it.  Anyone that has played this game always asks to play it again and that is a great testimonial of how fun it is.  Essentially you hold 6 random cards with beautiful illustrations on them.  Each player must decide on a card that matches the word or story told by the "story teller".  After each player selects a card that matches the story teller's word or story they lay their card face down with the other player's cards in the middle of the table.  The pile is shuffled and that cards are then flipped over and bet on. It's very light but very fun for the group.

Complexity: :halfstar: :nostar: :nostar: :nostar: :nostar:
Randomness: :star: :star: :star: :nostar: :nostar: 
Theme: :star: :star: :nostar: :nostar: :nostar:
Gameplay: :star: :star: :star: :star: :nostar:
Replayability: :star: :star: :star: :star: :nostar: 
Social interaction: :star: :star: :star: :star: :star:
Fun Factor: :star: :star: :star: :star: :nostar:
Components: :star: :star: :star: :star: :nostar:
Rules: :star: :star: :star: :nostar: :nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A very simple story-telling game where players take turns:
1. Choosing a picture from cards in their hand
2. Making a short (one sentence) story to describe the card (being as abstract as they want)
3. Other players pick cards from their hands that could match that story
4. Then players have to look at the picked cards and guess which one was played by the storyteller
Points are awarded to players who correctly guess, and to players who owned cards that others guessed.  The storyteller gets points for each person who got it right, unless everyone did, in which case the storyteller gets nothing.  The idea is to make the story clear enough that some people will guess, but not enough that everyone will.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
The first time I played this game, I loved it.  I thought it was so clever and innovative and beautiful.  The second time I played it, I didn't enjoy it nearly as much.  It doesn't seem like there is a "game" in here.  I will say that the 2nd play was with 9 players which makes the guessing next to impossible (with that many players, someone is bound to have a card that also matches the clue as well or better than the clue giver).  In the 2nd game, the new players loved it... but those playing for the 2nd time consistently felt it fell flat.  It seems like Dixit is more of a creativity exercise than a game.  And while there is nothing wrong with that, it is an exercise that gets old... in my case after a single play.

If you have a chance to play this game - I wholeheartedly recommend it.  You will almost certainly enjoy it.  I don't recommend buying.

RATING: 6
Pros
- Great artwork
- Fun casual game for a group of 5-6 people
- Very easy to teach

Cons
- You will see 90% of the cards in the box in one play-through, reducing replayability

A fun game that's easy to teach and enjoyable with a group of people; however, lack of replayability becomes a negative quickly, and I couldn't see myself losing several hours to this game wondering where the time went.

RATING: N/A
This game is so fun and yet so simple to play. I guess Dixit could actually work better if you know who you're playing with but it still works pretty well with "foreigners". Liked it a lot. Playable in all languages!

It needs expansions because if players most of the time are the same, which is more than normal as in a gaming group, a good bunch of pictures become obsolete and the re-playability suffers from that. Some of the drawings are ambiguous enough to allow some creativity when picking something to say while others are more obvious and players tend to think on them always in the same manner.

A good idea is to choose a theme to go for and try it but then again players should not exaggerate on creativity because that makes the game almost unplayable. I like to play Dixit with the certain amount of creativity and realism, sort of speaking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another Family/party game?  Ugh.  But wait.  This one has cool art and hold the phone: Thinking is involved.  This cool little game is good fun.  We player gets dealt a hand of cards.  The cards are all interesting paintings.  The storyteller, describes one of his cards and places it face down on the table and each other player adds a card to the pile.  Then the cards are mixed up and revealed.  The storyteller wants the others to pick his card, but he gets no points if every other player picks his card, so the “story” has to be descriptive enough for most of the other players to guess the right card but not obvious enough so everybody does.  

We haven’t turned this into a drinking game yet but I am sure that is on the horizon.

RATING: 6.6
Relaxing and fun with a good group. Kind of like Apples to Apples without the ridiculous subjectivity. Extremely well-designed game with a scoring mechanism that is self balancing - brilliant! Very swingy but in a good way.

A few minor negatives. The rabbit meeples are too light and the spaces on the board are too small. I found that if the board was bumped even a little, the pieces would be scattered. Also, I could see the image cards getting old after a few plays, but that's what expansions are for I suppose. 

Other than those things, it's a great light-hearted competitive and creative game.

RATING: 8.5
I'm not normally a fan of party games, but sometimes need something to play with non-gamers. Dixit is perfect for that. I can teach it to anybody in a minute or two, and I find it far more interesting and enjoyable than Apples to Apples, Cranium, or the other candidates out there.

The artwork on the cards is not only attractive, but perfectly suited to the requirements of the game. The artist can't be praised highly enough. The pictures are so evocative, detailed yet ambiguous, containing sufficient interesting details to support myriad associations and keep the game fresh through successive plays.


[update] This was the perfect game for our family gathering over the holidays. Everybody enjoyed it, and it was requested day after day. I'll definitely pick up Dixit 2 as well for the extra cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Wow, I can't believe the glowing reception this game is getting here.  After 2 plays I was done with it.  There are glaring problems with it--there are just not enough cards to keep it interesting for the story teller...after one play you've seen almost the entire deck.  If played with the same pool of people, it's far too easy to tailor the 'story' to people who've played with you before.  Its far too subject to shared experience clues which would be impossible for others to guess.  And it's far to subject to generation specific clues--clues given between 30 yearswill be impossible for someone in their 50s to get, for example.

To be honest, the game is borderline broken after just a few plays, and is certainly nearly impossible to bring new people into unless the experienced players purposefully handicap themselves to keep it interesting and remotely plausible for a new player to be competitive.

The only interesting thing that remains in the game is finding something in your own hand which might get picked for points.  Unfortunately that is extraordinarily luck-based as it is not uncommon to find absolutely nothing in your hand that even remotely has anything to do with the given clue.  Or on occasion, you might find something in our hand which matches the clue exactly, or even better than the card played by the storyteller.  Unfortunately this has nothing to do with any skill or wit used by the players.

For a similar style of game play you'll get FAR FAR more life out of the base set of Apples to Apples.

As a professional artist, I find it annoying that everyone professes how great the game will be for artists.  Yeah, interesting once or twice....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I digs it!  Such a brilliant little design, and brilliantly executed too!  Prior to learning the game, I just thought the art looked weird.  But after finally playing Dixit, I have a much greater appreciation for the artistic styling.  And most importantly, it's a very fun and funny game with the right number of people (I'm guessing 4-6 would be the sweet spot).  If I could complain about anything, it's that I wish there were more cards provided (though I guess that's been done through a few expansions).  And this complaint is nearly nullified when you consider the fact that not only are the cards oversized, but each of the 84 cards is an individual work of art.  I'm just not exactly sure what's up with those rabbit/squirrel meeples...  But great party game for a small group!  Game design: 4.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3.5/5  Total: 8/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of My All-Time Favorite Games. People can say it is basically Apples to Apples with a twist, but to me it is much more. I love the creative freedom this game allows. It's a game where you can say, act, squeal, or bark whatever you want with no rules to bog you down (e.g. taboo, pictionary). The cards contain beautifully designed artwork, and as it says so on the box itself, "a picture is worth a thousand words" as compared to 1 word/phrase (e.g. apples to apples, cards against humanity). While all the other games have their merits, to me Dixit brings out the best. 
Even when the winner was already determined we would still continue to play until the deck ran out just so that we can have the chance to give another hint or bait someone else into picking our card. I love it. What a wonderful game that is easy to teach and can be enjoyed by anyone. I guess the only vices to this game is that with multiple plays the cards may start getting redundant and people who do not enjoy games involving creative thinking may not get into the game as much. But generally, most people will enjoy this game. I found out that the game can be even MORE fun in teams of two. If you pair someone who isn't into creative thinking with someone who is, it usually becomes a more enjoyable experience for the uninterested. So this game scales well in bigger groups. I look forward to playing this game much more.

Artwork- 10
Ease to Teach- 10
Fun- 10
Mechanics- 9
Replay Value- 8
Strategy- 8
Theme- 8

63/70= 90%

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
[Libellud 2008 edition] {Party; creativity, story-telling; optimal 5-6p} Dixit is not a ground-breaking party game.  The voting mechanic (not to get all votes / no vote) is used in other games.  However, it does implement that system to its best.  Players really need to create a sentence / word / story so that it's neither too easy nor too difficult for other players to guess his card.

It has a potential to be a good party game.  It's easy to teach and learn.  It's fun.  It's interactive.  It can be wild with enough creativity.  It's language neutral.  I have a worry that its replayability is not good (Well, all similar games, such as Pictionary, Squint, etc. have the same problem.)  In all, I highly recommend this party game.  (French games are usually special in a collection: likely to be fresh and entertaining.)

Dixit is a beautiful game.  The components are nicely illustrated and are stylish.  The cards are stunningly beautiful and colorful.  The rabbit pawns are vivid.  If each voting token was uniquely illustrated, it'd be perfect.

This is an excellent game from first-time designer.  Looking forward to more Jean-Louis's games!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Trattenete il fiato! Le immagini sono state rivelate. Hanno tutte una cosa in comune: una frase enigmatica. Ora state attenti, solo una delle immagini e' la chiave. Usate fiuto e intuizione per trovarla, evitando le trappole degli altri giocatori. 
Dixit è un gioco di carte che fa della narrazione la sua meccanica di base. E' davvero un gioco sorprendente, conviviale e divertente da giocare in famiglia e con gli amici.

Contenuti
1 piano di gioco nella scatola
84 carte
36 segnalini voto in 6 colori diversi, numerati da 1 a 6
6 conigli in legno

RATING: 5.5
I was interested in trying this game because I thought it would be a good experience for my kids...work a creative part of their brain.

After playing it...I don't like it.  I really don't enjoy giving the clues.  We are not that great in giving clues as a family either so the answer tends to be obvious.  I do kind of like trying to tailor a clue to someone to try to improve my score but it's just not enough for me to want to keep it.  I liked it the first time because the cards have fascinating/weird art work.  Once you have seen them all though it was hard to give new clues each time we play.

My 5 year old daughter likes it a lot though.

RATING: 8
Very fun party game. It's quite metagame dependent though - you might get pissed if a subset of your group kept using in-jokes or internet memes to collude for points. Played with close friends from similar backgrounds, this is the ultimate party game. However, in a mixed group, the "right" way to play Dixit is to try to exclude the people who are *least* in the inner circles - which can make Dixit an incredibly insular and mean game, least fun for those who need to be included the most.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Relating to Apples to Apples (which I loathe) I love this game for two main reasons:

1. It uses your imagination.
2. There is not just one judge deciding the random lucky winner. It uses a voting system.

Those two simple combinations make the game enjoyable to me. 

Apple to Apples gets very old, even when playing with a different group. Since Dixit uses your imagination, every time you play with a different group, there are lots of laughs because of all the crazy ideas people have as to what the cards remind people of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Best play with people you dont know, because a winning strategy is , boringly, to give clues your partner knows. Which is very boring the second time.

RATING: 8
Awesome game for such simple rules. If you take on the scoring, even small kids can play it.

Another thing which makes this game great is that it's vastly different depending on the people you play with. Everyone has a different mind and you can see that very clearly in this game.

After some plays when you see the same cards again and again, you wish for all fresh ones but for that they made expansions.

It's an imaginative game without theme or real goal but just for the sake of imagining things. If you can live with that, get it!

There is a lot of opportunity for different cards to appeal to very different themes because of all the little subtle details.  Rating up but still probably won't play it that often. 2009/07/05

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I typically describe this game to friends a Apples to Apples with French surrealist artwork. While it isn't necessarily the best description of the game, it tends to get people on board quickly.

Like Apples to Apples this is a game about knowing the people you play with. It has a slightly more complicated scoring system that, in practice, creates a nice tension between making clues too difficult and too easy. There's a sense of creative license here that simply isn't found in Apples to Apples and is found to a still-lesser extent in Cards Against Humanity. And it's that combination of solid, tested party-game mechanics with creative spice that makes this game so brilliant at the table.

I feel like this game is deserving of a ten. The artwork alone makes me think I'll always enjoy leafing through the cards ... we'll see how I feel in a half-year or so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Feels a bit like a roleplaying game, in that players have to want to play along to get any real experience. Good fun with the right players, though.

Weaker points is the ability for sub-groups of players to form "knowledge-circles", where say two couples will consistently guess each other's clues, but never the other couple's, which makes the game insular rather than encompassing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It works as a party game if you dont like party games this will not work for you. It's not really unique as I think the scoring mechanic is based on Balderdash or something that came later. The clever part is where you subtely suggest the card but not say it overtly. After the novelty wears off I am not sure how much more I want to play it. It is repetitive which is a similar concern, i.e. the game state doesnt really change it's the same thing over and over. The rating is more about how well the game works, how clean the rules are, if I had to rate on how enthused I am about playing it again more like 6.5

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a light, party-type game in the lineage of Apples to Apples that uses (beautiful) illustrations instead of words. To its credit, it is certainly more creative than A2As and more of a "game" in its scoring and judging mechanics. While the illustrations are wonderful, one downside to the game is that you'll most likely cycle through them all in a single play through. I do not really find this a detraction, but if you do, you can always buy the expansions to add more cards to the game. Overall, an enjoyable take on the A2A formula that requires a certain level of buy-in and creativity from its players.

RATING: 9.5
Dixit is excellent for many reasons. For one, it's an accessible game to all ages. I've played this with family, friends, non-gamers, gamers, and children (7+).

It's a simple yet elegant game with amazing art. Give a clue that isn't too obvious, but obvious enough at least 1 other person will get it. The art work is awesome and there's times where you're like "Wow, everyone's clue is really good".

I never hesitate to pull this one out in casual situations.

RATING: N/A
#Players: 3-6
Time: 30 mins
Mechanic: Voting

Choose one of the insane pictures from your hand and give a clue that will lead some, not all, of the players to guess which card it is. All other players will play a card which could also match the hint given. All cards are shuffled and then the other players vote on which card they think is yours.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Eleinte ódzkodtam tôle, mert ezek a mesélôs játékok nem igazán jönnek be, de akkor még nem tudtam mirôl van szó. Anno régen, kb 30 évvel ezelôtt mi mûár játszottunk ilyet:  valaki az Értelmezô Kéziszótárból kinézett egy olyan szót, amit senki sem ismert , majd mindenki a fantáziája alapján írt az adott szóhoz egy jelentést. És ugyanúgy ahogy itt is, a végén a "mesélô" felolvasta a magyarázatokat, amelyek között ott volt persze a valós is. Aki eltalálta a valóst pontot kapott, akinek a magyarázatára szavazott valaki szintén pontot kapott. Most olvastam Simulacrumnál hogy már van egy nagyon hasonló játék: Defintiy

Féltem, hogy a kártyák kicsi klesznek, de ezk a nagy lapok nagyszerûek. Tény, hogy a rajzokhoz "elborult" elme kellett:D de nagyon jók.  A pontozás brilliáns: hiába játszod egy összeszokott társasággal, rá vagy kényszerítve hogy mindig új dolgot találj ki egy adott kártyához, különben nem kapsz pontot! Az egyetlen kis gixer: hogyha a társaságban van olyan, aki valamilyen szempontból "kilóg" a többiek közül, akkor ezt "meg lehet lovagolni" és kissé lehet befolyásolni tudatosan a pontokat. Például a játékosok között vannak hárman, akik egy osztályba jártak a középiskolában és az egyik tanárra tettek valamilyen becenevet. Akkor a többi játékos számára ez a becenév nem jelent semmit. A mesélô ehhez a becenévhez tesz ki kártyát és nyilvánvaló, hogy lesznek akik el fogják találni:)

A pontozósáv ötletes, tetszik; hogy miért pont nyulak a bábuk? Ez a sok elvont rajz után már nem is kérdés ; akár kilyukadt fürdôkádak is lehetnének;)

RATING: 7
A highly enjoyable lateral-thinking party game for the whole family. The artwork is quite lovely and has many ways it can be interpreted.  The rules are very explainable for the most part (the scoring can confuse non gamers and kids.)  Its easy to pick up and play and very versatile.  I'd like for it to be a "Party" game though rather than playing such a small group as it does out of the box... but that's what expansions are for.

RATING: N/A
Players: 3-6
Time: 30 Min
Complexity (1-5): 1.27
Mechanic: Storytelling / Voting
Notes:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
‘Dixit’ is a game with light rules that nonetheless manages to tap deep aspects of social cognition. If you are a person who revels in acts of interpretation, who enjoys reading people as much as exploring layers of subtext in literature and the visual arts, then chances are you will appreciate the unique invitation that ‘Dixit’ represents. It is an invitation to play with meaning.

Players are dealt hands of cards, with each card bearing a unique complex image. There are two basic roles for players. In the primary role, you will be asked to select a card from your hand (unbeknownst to other players) and use it to create an utterance that “matches” the image. That’s right, any utterance. You can recite the whole Gettysburg Address (in Klingon, if you wish); you can hum a few bars of ‘Ain’t Misbehavin’; or you can issue a monosyllabic grunt. But you should know that for whatever utterance you do make, the other players, in keeping with their secondary role, will secretly choose one image from their own hands that they feel best matches your “hint”. Then you will gather the cards bearing their selections, shuffle them, and spread them out onto the table such that your own card is included amongst the many foils.

After scrutinizing the the images, the other players will then simultaneously indicate which on display is the “true” inspiration of your utterance. Scoring is structured so that you are rewarded for offering clever clues–meaning an utterance that is neither too hard nor too easy to interpret. (If either everyone or no one chooses your card, you get bupkis.) In their secondary roles, other players will score points if they correctly interpret your utterance, and/or if they manage to deceive other players into choosing *their* foil.

Similar metacognitive “voting” mechanisms have been used before. But what makes ‘Dixit’ tick–and in an astonishingly novel way–is the artwork on the cards. Simply put, ‘Dixit’ features the most brilliantly evocative art that I’ve encountered in any game, bar none. Marie Cardouat has graced the game with hundreds of little expressionist gems that look as if they were pulled from the pages of a Jungian fairy tale. In terms of style, the illustrations are at times childlike, dreamlike, and often are subtly unsettling. Like imagery on Tarot cards, Cardouat’s compositions beg to be puzzled over. And in this capacity, they preserve the most crucial functionality of the game.

Ultimately, what makes the ‘Dixit’ worth returning to again and again, is its easy enchantment, not only with respect to what is “seen” in the cards, but in the predictions you are asked to make about others’ interpretations, and vice versa. The poetry cuts both ways, as you are both the interpreter and a text that is being interpreted. This also means that the tenor of the game is highly influenced by the personality of the individuals playing it. Depending on the group, your game may be punctuated by introspective “Aha’s” or by raucous laughter. Or both. To me, this is not just the sign of a great party game, but of a great game period.

RATING: 4
Well...kind of ok game. It's a lot like "Nobody's perfect" except that instead of words this is about pictures. There isn't much going on and there are similiar Partygames which are much better for laughs. I would play it again, but Dixit is just not funny enough to be a good party game. I guess I don't need to mention, that it also lacks the depth to be a "real" game. So yeah...Dixit ends up in the no mans land of being a simple party game that's just not terribly funny.

RATING: 10
Absolutely brilliant. I have played this game with many people and it always seems to make for a good time. It is thoughtful, deep, interactive, creative, social and great for bonding with friends and family. The artwork is gorgeous, and if you ever get sick of them, there are plenty of expansions to mix it up. This is what Cards Against Humanity should have been - it can be just as funny, yet with more choice, more thinking, and more bonding with those around you. The insights you get into the people you are playing with are much more gratifying than who can draw the dirtiest card. I will never tire of this game, and it will stay in my collection forever. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This is one of those games that is only as fun as the people playing it.  True of any party game, I guess.  I would probably give this game a lower score if my nieces and nephews didn't love it so much.  The mark of any good party game is the laughter it creates and this one seems to have an abundance of it.  The kids are fully engaged and thoroughly entertained while playing this game with us.  Adults must play fairly with the kids, though, because adults can easily give clues that the kids don't understand and outscore them.  If you are looking for a fun game that won't exclude the kids, then this is a great choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is best with the full complement (6 players), but it is still very fun with 4 and certainly 5. The card art is quite good and thought provoking for the most part, but there are some that could have a little more detail. Anyway, the idea of the game is nothing new, but is quite fun as it really brings out the creative side of people and it is a nice little challenge to try to guess what the story teller was thinking. Must be played with the right crowd to be good though.

RATING: 2
The game concept is fantastic:  Balderdash with pictures instead of words.  But the card art is deeply disturbing.  At best, the people depicted are melancholy.  Most appear to be wildly depressed.  Candles drip blood, a mounted deer head cries while a cat watches, a couple lives inside a grinder... I feel like I'm taking a Rorschach test.  Awful.

RATING: 7.5
[u]Fantasy, Imagination & Creativity[/u]

● [b]pros[/b] [i]creative thinking, great artwork, quick play-time and can be scaled in play-time, high value, unique mechanics and gameplay, communicative[/i]
● [b]cons[/b] [i]replay-value especially with same players, insider-hints amongst best friends/family/couples[/i]

Also owned:
[geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/55660/qubic]Dixit 2: Quest[/geekurl]
[geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/156189/qubic]Dixit: Daydreams (2014 Edition)[/geekurl]

[b][i]● Custom foamcore boardgame-insert
● Sleeved in SwanPanasia Standard 80mm x 122mm[/b][/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
This should be called "Ditch this"! "Hey, I have an idea. We can play this game that won the Spiel des Jahres award in 1985 - no - I mean, in 2010. The one with the beautiful and elegant Little Prince artworks, that could be found in lots of children's books. The one where we can rave about how it inspires the fantasy because of these tremendous illustrations and then find out that it's best to only say one word describing the pictures as opposed to tell a real story, because you didn't offer any contact surface and keeping it vague is way better as it fits better to more pictures. The one where we can drink some wine as it fits to the elegance of the whole game and we won't be in danger of spilling the costly wine we're drinking while playing this game, because there won't be laugh attacks like in Nobody's perfect. Or any of the fun from Cluzzle from which it also copied mechanisms." 

Now on a serious note: I feel disillusioned that this won Spiel des Jahres. In a way it compares to Nobodys perfect. A game from almost 20 years ago. And it doesn't even vaguely come close. And this one wins Spiel des Jahres? What drove their minds? It's so arbitrary to say "Let's go with party games this year" no matter what else was released. If you look at the nominees it seems like this was the decision making progress. For me this is hardly a game and I'm in total disbelief as to how many people buy into the hype.

I'd rather play Monopoly.

RATING: 8
'Dixit 1' - original game. 

Cons: Only material for 6 players and board (score track) integrated as part of box. Only room for one set of cards. Dixit Odyssey fixed all these issues. Get that too!

Great game for both gamers and non-gamers of all ages. Love the odd, imaginative, dreamlike images. The game benefits from multiple expansions. 

I have eight set of 84 cards so far (i.e. 672 in total). I typically use ~84 cards for each game but change set from round to round. I have mixed up the first four sets but so far kept the newest sets separate due to their differences in drawing style and mood. However, I could see mixing these up if the decks grow old. 

Overview images of each set of 84 cards are available from the Dixit homepage to allow sorting the cards back into the original sets.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Like Cards Against Humanity, there doesn't seem to be much replayability. Once you've seen all of the cards then future plays aren't as fun, and the gameplay isn't all that interesting to begin with.

Update: Another issue with the game is that your best move can sometimes be really unfun for most of the group. For instance, in a recent game I gave a clue that was basically an inside joke between myself and one of the players. Since the clue was essentially a made-up word for which the other players had no reference, they just had to hope to get some points completely at random.

There can also be an issue if there is a generation gap between some of the players, or if they have completely different knowledge backgrounds.

After more plays, I still don't see why this game is so appealing to so many gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dixit is a fun 30 minute game where you can come up with the most random words or sentence to have some of your play mates guess your card :) 

I have had a few games now with board-gamers and non-board-gamers. This has created some interesting moments trying to guess which one was the players card or just choosing the right card to put down. Also I won one game :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the most original games (if not the most) I have ever played. The art on the cards is stunningly beautiful and creative, and the mechanic super simple yet highly replayable because it counts on your imagination to make the most of it. I think you need to be with the right people to play it (I know many hardcore gamers that are "meh" about it, they'd rather throw at each other's throats with a war game than play this) but at the same time is very friendly for new players or some public not used to complex board games. I enjoy it as a filler really, but wouldn't base my whole evening on playing this because it can become repetitive and boring after some time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fabulous game made fabulous because of the artwork on tarot-sized cards.  It is also a bit more "open" than say a game like Faces.

Easily my favorite group/party game.  I will buy EVERY expansion.

One downside to the game is that the artwork is so fun that once players have played the game a few times and seen all of the artwork it takes away a bit of the original magic of the anticipation of a new card.  This complaint only exists because the game is so outstandingly beautiful and whimsical. 

Update:  After 20 more plays with a variety of people this still holds up for me.  I have gotten over the artwork issue I wrote about before.  I think everyone goes through that as those pictures are so great, but the gameplay holds up beautifully for an incredibly wide range of kids and adults.  

For Sale used to be my "go to" game for a new group of non-gamers.  Dixit blows it away. It is just more fun.

I commented above that I would buy every expansion.  That might be true still, but I have purposely held off buying Dixit 3 as I find the artwork to be inferior and it does not lend itself to storytelling the way the previous artwork did.  I will only buy it to cherry pick a few cards worthy of its predecessors and to get the board and voting cards.  I am not in a hurry to do this however and I will only buy it when I find a cheap copy.

Update: I still think this is a great game. However, I have softened on my aversion to new expansions with "inferior" art. I buy them, but only the ones I like. None have ever been as whimsical or open to interpretation as the original art by Marie Cardouat and I do believe the expansions have diluted the card pool. Still having more cards has become imperative because of all of the play this gets. I started to hear the same stories.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 3
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 3
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 5
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 5


Overall - 3.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
Torture....cleverly disguised as a board game.

In the 1960's the Rorschach,  commonly known as the ink blot,  was the most widely used projective test.

In 2003 a report was published that stated claims made by proponents were found to be less than favorable, but that the test possessed "validity greater than chance".  A ringing endorsement indeed.

Fast forward to the year 2008 and this kitsch is thrust upon us and manages to amass somewhere in the neighborhood of 1000 fans. 20,000 owners and a rating hovering just shy of the stratosphere - all on the greatest board game resource on the planet.

Different strokes and all.....but I am left mind- numbingly perplexed.  The art, which generally receives accolades, struck me as extremely maudlin - portending the dour experience that,  no doubt,   was soon to follow.  In that respect at least,  Dixit did not fail to  fulfill it's promise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a very unique game that stimulates your imagination in a very elegant way. It's also fun and tense from the first minute till the last, while it also takes less than a minute to explain to new players.

Everyone I've introduced this to was fascinated, but after a dozen or so plays it gets repetitive. The main problem is that it gets progressively more difficult to enjoy or even play the game as you exaust your imagination describing the same cards over and over - never using the same description twice (or you more or less cheat). The expansion will probably help, but for how long I wonder? Best play this once in a while with a varying group.

It also has the worst board and pieces I've ever seen in a game. Plain horrible, and completely impractical. Thankfully the cards are pieces of art and sturdy.

Overall this game is like an explosion, it's great at first but whizzles away after more plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is a fun, creative party game that takes the premise of Apples to Apples, but effectively changes and challenges it enough that the hardcore BGGers will not snort derisively at being invited to play. Ultimately there are a fair number of ways to use player familiarity to "game" the system, but it's a rather non-competitive party game and if you are doing that you're probably a dick. It is light fare, but still rather fun and offers other ways to enjoy the game even without being "deep" into the system. It is not a gateway game, but a nice bridge to occupy a mixed group of gamers and non-gamers for part of the evening, or until the rest of the gaming group arrives or finishes their other game.

Full review at: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/564809/
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Here is the thing. This might not actually be my most favorite game ever, but I do enjoy it a lot. The reason I have to rate it this highly is because I have found that it is THE best game to play with non-gamers. I have even managed to get people who dislike games to play this. It even works with those who are usually pretty sore about losing.

It's such a creative an original title that challenges you in a completely different way from other board games and I appreciate that a lot. 

It's fun, it's short and it is going to guarantee a good time with almost anyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gorgeous card game, of which there seem to be more and more of late (such as Krakow 1325 AD and Day & Night). Interestingly, all three are first-time designers and small publishers, who all clearly put a lot of energy into the art on the cards in their respective games. Dixit is not only beautiful, but also a clever party game. It's not entirely original, feeling like a mix of many previous party games (such as Apples to Apples, Balderdash, and Cluzzle), but it's original enough to be worth playing and purchasing in my opinion. I've played the game eight times so far and with a wide variety of different groups and it's gone over well every time. There's something about the illustrations combined with the simple yet challenging gameplay that gives this one a remarkably wide appeal.

Purchased: November 3, 2009

RATING: 7.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A lovely idea where you choose a word and associate that with a card...you then submit that card, and other plays choose a card that they hope will fit your word.

These are shuffled, and dealt out.  Each player then declares which one they think was the original.  

You get points based on how many people guess right, with none being awarded if everyone else guesses right, or if no one guesses at all.  It's finding that balance.

Made more fun if you can only use sounds to describe the pictures!  

Cards repeat quickly though, so perhaps need the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple and brilliant game. Most people seem to love it. Great hit with kids and family.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good:
-Gateway game
-Not very competitive
-More replayability than other games in genre
-Theming is universal
-Amazingly simple rules

Bad:
-Not enough cards in the base game
-Cards too big for standard sleeves
-Scoring tokens fall too easily
-Some players take too long to come up with clues
-Too unstructured selection process for some
-Not for hardcore gamers
-Can be frustrating when you are the group's outsider

Overall:
A game so fun and accessible that it teeters on being a party game.  Unfortunately, hardcore gamers are baffled by the appeal.  If you like Apples to Apples switch to this and enjoy a deeper and more creative game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.4
MUITO divertido! Rápido, muito fácil, leve, lúdico, animado, integrador, ... Enfim, não tenho adjetivos para definir esse party game na essência da palavra. Pode inclusive desbancar o Love Letter e o Zombie Dice como entrada para qualquer não gamer. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a neat, unique game when you want something light and a little party-game-ish, but still want a thoughtful game too. The artwork is just incredibly beautiful, and you'll find yourself picking out new details all the time. A big part of the game is knowing who you're playing with - a phrase that might be perfect in one crowd might be terrible with another. So there's a bit more to the game than just word association, as it might initially appear. This also helps with replay value - unless you're constantly playing with the same group, you'll often pick new phrases even for cards that you've played before.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dear Dixit,  Please come up with a 2P/duel version of this game.  Sincerely, someone who plays mostly 2P.

In all seriousness, I love this game.  Everything about it appeals to me.  It has gorgeous, unique artwork.  It has tons of expansions to increase replayability.  It encourages creativity and abstract thinking.  It feels like a social game, but is causal enough to pull i n even the shyer players who don't like most party/social games.

We've usually had scores end up pretty close, even when one person does get ahead for awhile.  Even if you aren't winning, you're almost always having a good time.  There are lots of laughs involved and not too much time to worry about being AP.  In other words, it's so fun you won't be agonizing that every move might be the one to put you behind in points.

Unfortunately, I play mostly 2P and only get to pull this out when visiting family.  Since it's such a nice, light game that works for all ages and types of gamers, it's really a perfect game.  We've tried to come up with alternate 2P scoring, but haven't yet.  If Dixit ever does come up with something like that, I'd probably rate it a 9-10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I feel the game is a bit over-rated, but it is very solid fun.  I do agree it's a must have in any collection because few games have such wide appeal and easy rules.  It boils down what I enjoyed about previous games such as Balderdash and Apples to Apples, and delivers the experience with fascinating card art.

There can be hang-ups if people aren't particularly creative, you can get stuck with some hard to work with cards, but overall it's an enjoyable experience with some laughs.  Wish it could accommodate a few more players.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I like this "Apples to Apples-esque" game quite a lot, though I definitely recommend getting one or more of the expansions, as the additional cards prevent the pictures from becoming too familiar. I've had as much fun playing this with my college friends as with my family. Big thumbs up!

Edit (7/18/2014): Dixit (including the first 2 expansions, which I never play without) has really grown on me over the years. It is my favorite family/party game in my collection, and it's a damn shame that I don't get to play it more often. What I love most about Dixit is the amount of room for creativity within that core Apples to Apples system. While I still own Apples to Apples, Dixit has more or less replaced it, as everything the former does, the latter pulls off better and in a more elegant package. Dixit is one of the few games I own that I can honestly say that I will never part with (not willingly, at least). It is an absolute treasure!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
All Dixit versions are beautiful. The way you tell stories with car with just a single word or sentence is a genius idea. It was a revolution in the boardgame history. Since, we speak about the french game (like eurogames but with artwork).
However, all Dixit versions have the same problem : scoring. I find the scoring boring. It break the game rythm. And since Mysterium was released, it's worse cause this last one show how to score, win or loose keeping the game rythm.
So, play Dixit without point or use your Dixit cards to play Mysterium ;-)

RATING: 3
I want my party game to be like a party.  Dixit is more like a a trip to a bad art gallery.  Some people, both in my game group, and on BGG, really adore this game, but I don't find much to hold my attention.  The game mechanics are similar to [gameid=74] with an everybody-votes twist.  I really don't like this mechanic, but was hoping that the art would save this game.  The art, while interesting, is not to my taste.  I prefer my party games to have shouting and acting and wordplay and group play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this is either the type of game that you love or you hate.  Personally, I love trying to figure out just the right clue to coax 1 or 2 other people to pick my card, as well as the challenge of picking a card to try and match the other player's clues.  So simple that it's easy to play with non-gamers, but interesting enough to keep gamers interested.

After three plays, this game is a brilliant exercise in knowing your friends. Beautiful art, gentle, chatty, and great with non-gamers. The only thing stopping it getting a ten is the limited range of cards.

Finally, finally got to own this art-object-cum-game. It is absolutely beautiful, utterly charming. I can't explain how much I love just looking at Dixit... The box, the cards, the bunny meeples... It oozes charm. 

[NB: Been fighting Jon for ages about Dixit. He hates games like Dixit and doesn't think I can find two other people who will like it. I pointed out that the game was quite cheap for a 84 beautifully-printed cartoons].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
i dont understand the name dixit, nor i get what the theme is, so i'll  just look at the gameplay

the rules are very simple, guessing picture (with a bit of twist). i like the scoring mechanic, i think it's fair. the strategy changes a bit with the number of players, but it's still okay (3 players game is not recommended though). there is a bit luck dependence though : it's easy to get points when our card matches people's story, and very hard when it never match (because not everyone is a good storyteller). the playing time isn't really important, you can actually prolong or stop the game anytime you wish

the artworks are kind of abstract, but it suits the gameplay. otherwise the picture style is okay. the card size is big, but it's needed so we can look at the picture clearer. the amount of cards is too few though, it should have been made to accommodate the number of players nicely

this game is best played with people having the same amount of knowledge, otherwise you'll have hard time to adjust yourself to the group. it's because dixit is a party game without strong theme. i rate this game 8.5+

RATING: N/A
6p
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The only way to consider this game is as a party game, and in that respect, it's a pretty good one.  It encourages interaction and discussion, and it's enjoyable for players in both roles, as either a storyteller or a picker.  So ultimately, the game has to be viewed as how it works more as an experience, less as a game.  In that respect, it works, and it works well.  It just has a weird scoring mechanism, which in turn makes it more reasonable for a storyteller to be so vague as to be almost incomprehensible, since it's best to have only one player pick your card, instead of more than one player.  Still, it's a minor issue, as the game could be played without keeping any score at all.

2 plays: 4 players

-----

Base game
2
2012 Special Cards

RATING: 8
Wow this game is amazing.

One caveat: some people have said that "playing to win" involves being creative. That is not true - truly playing to win as the storyteller involves picking the player who is the farthest behind and giving a clue that only he can guess. This is obviously pretty lame, as it can be really easy to do ("Ted and I saw one of these yesterday, while you two were out at the spa").

Fortunately, you don't have to play to win, and when you don't, the game is gobs of fun. Love the art. I'm not sure if I'll ever go back to Apples to Apples.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great artwork, and an interesting game to boot. Not exactly a party game, but kind of in between.  It does take some effort to come up with the "good but not too good" phrase. But it's so open-ended that it's completely replayable. I have no idea why people are complaining that it's not (as if there's just one word/phrase per card).

The scoring is interesting, though it's a little wonky because you must guess something different than your own card, so you can get some lucky breaks here and there, some accidental big scores for people who just basically threw a random card in.  But it's very good, and WAY better than A2A.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Dixit is nothing more than a set of rules to make you say interesting things. You can forget keeping score, just let the game flow and your brains bloom.
It's a brilliant idea.
This was the game that convinced me that there is somehow more to modern board games. It is the game that feels closest to being art.

It can fail with a bad group (people not only insisting to play for points, but actually doing just that, and nothing more), but that says more about the group than the game for me.

I'm also really attached to this game because at this point I literally spent weeks making my own cards. Not to mention playing with them with friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An easy to learn game, where you have to guess how the other players think.

One player is the storyteller for the turn and looks at the images on the 6 cards in her hand. From one of these, she makes up a sentence and says it out loud. Each player selects the card in their hands which best matches the sentence. All the pictures are shown face up and every player has to bet upon which card was the storyteller's. If everyone guess the storyteller's card, the storyteller get no points. So you have to be descriptive, but not too descriptive.

RATING: 7
Lots of fun to be had in this medium-size group party game.  One person, the story teller, comes up with a wacky phrase to describe an image, and the rest of the group all picks which of their card illustrates the phrase best.  Everyone votes on which card was the story tellers - lots of fun ensues.  The neat twist is that the clues have to be good enough to have someone guess the right card, but not too easy that everyone guesses right.  Lots of fun, and a very original game.

RATING: 7
What I like:
-Each illustrated card can be interpreted many different ways.
-The current player's clue doesn't have to be a word or phrase, but can be an Action, a poem, an interpretive dance, etc.
-There are lots of expansions.
-Great for all ages.

What I don't like:
-If you only have one copy, without expansions, we always go through the entire deck about 75% into the game and have to shuffle and reuse cards.

TL;DR  If you enjoy party games, definitely play Dixie.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Smash hit.  A blast at parties or family gatherings. I personally love it because of easy teachability and it tickles the imagination of all players.  

Simple, brilliant idea for a game.  Game rules:  Look at a beautiful piece of artwork, come up with a caption, score points.  Then laugh--a lot.  This game delivers fun, laughter, imaginative play, and re-playability.

Many party games that force players to use their imagination fall flat.  Most people are shy in a crowd about sharing any imaginative thought their mind springs forth, so they shut down.  Those games then become slogging affairs.

Dixit fixes this with requiring only one sentence (or less) descriptions of pictures that open your mind up to ANYTHING.  These aren't pictures of a flower pot or dead fruit.  They are pictures of babies floating in an ocean of red, or toy soldiers jumping into the sunset.  Beautiful, fantastic artwork. 

Games go so quickly that you end up reshuffling and starting again.  The only lag in play may be a few people refreshing their drinks (or themselves).  

An instant classic which definitely will see my gaming table many times this 2011 holiday season.  :)            
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
"Dixit or die trying" as my friend says.

GREAT party game (about 20 games in July, about 50 in all summer 2009, over 80 games at all).

RATING: 7
Interesting game with a potential to be hilarious in some groups (at parties, with a wild fantasy). Though it feels, like it lacks something. It is hard to bluff in this game. Also there is a place for cheating, when putting out completely not matching cards to be able to point storyteller's card. Though probably it can be counteracted and also makes the storyteller to come up with a very clever sentences. What i actually dislike is that board, which makes box huge. It would suffice to have notepad and pencils to keep the scores. This game is about the cards mainly, so i would want to take actually the inside box only with cards and markers and a small condensed rule book. Price would be smaller as well and it would be easier to take on the trip.

RATING: N/A
Each round, the judge picks a card showing some kind of artistic design from their hand and gives a short clue. The other players must also pick a card form their hand that the clue could indicate. The cards are shuffled up, and the players must try to guess the judge's card.

RATING: 7.5
Intriguing gameplay coupled with good artwork and substantial player interaction. It is also easy enough to teach, making it a suitable family game. However, it may not be suitable with a very diverse group of people, as the phrase or sentence made will reflect the player's background and probably only those with similar background may be able to guess correctly. Replayability may also be on the low side as the number of cards is limited, so many new cards with different pictures are required to keep it fresh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dixit is an enjoyable game, but I have a hard time calling it a party game, a light family game seems more fitting in my opinion. It's a good game, but not exactly laugh out loud funny.

Dixit is a gorgeous game, but for as good as the cards look, it's amazing how you sometimes feel completely stumped as the storyteller looking at your hand of six cards. After playing the original title, you will surely lust after Dixit 2 and Dixit Odyssey to add more cards to your collection.

I will not be play Dixit with my gaming buddies, but my wife and daughters love it! That alone earns it a high rating from me. It's the kind of game that you can teach to anyone, and with Dixit Odyssey you can play it with up to 12, and it becomes more of an actual party game.

It should be noted that Dixit Odyssey is a better implementation of the game, with better player pawns, score board, voting system, etc. If you have yet to play the game, I recommend that you first pick up Dixit Odyssey.

RATING: 8
Great party game, gets people talking and thinking out of the box. Light mood, light gameplay. I have just the base game, and I suspect it strongly benefits from having some expansions. After a few games, you know all the picture cards, and I have yet to play a game that ends by score rather than by running out of cards. More variety would keep veteran players from strategically hinting to draw out specific cards.

RATING: 8
Loaned to Mum

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wunderschön illustrierte Karten und schnell erklärte Regeln: Ein Spieler gibt einer seiner Handkarten einen Titel oder eine Umschreibung. Die anderen legen Karten ab, die ebenfalls dazu passen. Dann werden die gemischten Karten ausgelegt und jeder rät, welches die ursprüngliche Karte war.
Ein Spiel, das auf jeden Fall die Fantasie fördert. Man bekommt nämlich als "Erzähler" nur Punkte, wenn ein Teil der Mitspieler richtig liegt. Sei nicht zu offensichtlich... und nicht zu abstrakt.
